div.p: A Fool's Preferment, OR, THE Three DUKES of Dunstable.
A COMEDY. As it was Acted at the Queens Theatre in Dorset-Garden, by Their MAJESTIES Servants.
Written by Mr. D'urfey.
Together, with all the SONGS and NOTES to 'em, Excellently Compos'd by Mr. HENRY PURCELL. 1688.
Licensed, May 21. 1688. R. P.

q.l: Eupolis atque Cratinus, Aristophanesque Poetae,
Atqque alii, quorum Comoedia prisca virorum est;
Si quis erat dignus deseribi, quod Malus, aut Fur,
Quod Moechus foret, aut Sicarius, aut alioqui
Famosus; multa cum libertate notabunt.
Hinc Omnis pendet Lucillius.—

div.p: Printed for Ios. Knight, and Fra. Saunders at the Blue Anchor in the Lower Walk of the New Exchange in the Strand, 1688.

div.head: TO THE HONOURABLE CHARLES Lord MORPETH.
div.p:
I Am in Debt so many ways, for Obligations to your Self, and Noble Family, that, with all the Gratitude I have, I am puzzled in finding occasions to express my Thanks; be pleased therefore to receive in a Dedication of this flight Piece, my Hearts true Acknowledgments, and as true an Endeavour to dievrt you, by Reading a Comedy, which was only design'd to please such as look on this sort of Dramatick Poesie, as you do, with Judgment and good Humour. I have studied these things long enough to know the Humor of the Town, and what is proper for Diversion; but I cannot always bring my Inclinations to flatter the (Would be WITS,) nor spare the exposing a notorious Vice, thô the price of a Third Day were the fatal consequence of such an Indiscretion: It is, and shall be, enough for me at any time, if some few of the many Noble and Worthy Persons, that did me the Honour to appear for me, in spite of the Party that was malitiously made by some eminent Gamesters of both Sexes, who thought themselves touch'd: If such as your Lordship, and those others of my unbyass'd Friends, will please to think it worth their liking, and alluding to a late Honourable, and Renowned Author; I Declare,
If You, and Others, I omit to Name,
Approve my Lines, I count your Censure, Fame.

As to the Play, I will only say this of it, the first hint was taken from an old Comedy of Fletcher's; and as it was improv'd, and several new Humours added, it was generally lik'd before the Acting. I knew Basset was a Game, only proper for Persons of great Fortunes; and therefore I thought, that a wholsome Satyr of this kind might have oblig'd some Country-Gentlemen; or Citizens of small Estates, whose Wives ne're heeding the approaching Ruin, took only care, they might have the Honour, to be seen at Play with Quality. But some certain, very nice, Persons, especially one, took it so to Heart, that dear Basset should be expos'd, that my honest Intentions were quite frustrated, and that the Piece might be sure to be ruin'd, their Majesties were told, it was so obscene, that it was not fit to be Acted; when, I can prove, there has not, these seven years, been any Comedy so free from it; and some good Judges were pleas'd to Declare, they thought that, the only Reason some People had to find fault. Obscenity is a thing of that abominable Nature, that unless it be detected so throughly, that it may be punished, it were better not heeded at all, (especially, by a Lady) who, in my Opinion, being too Witty in such a Discovery, will only give People to understand, how well skill'd She is in the Matter.

My LORD, I most Humbly beg your Lordships Pardon for this Digression, thô I could not well Publish the Play, without some Defence in this kind; but I have done with 'em now, and the hottest Censurer shall at leisure cool of himself: I will only rally my own ill Fortune, and say, with that admirable French Moralist; Fortune, Ie me repends de t'voir suivie, & cognoissant que tu ne peux chos. du monde advoüë que la vertu est le seul port où les hommes peuvent-trouver leur veritable tranquillité.

A Sentence, which, I'm sure, your Lordship throughly understands, having been with choicest Care Bred, and Learned in the nicest Rudiments of Morality, Wit, and Religion, and therefore skill'd in what concerns all Mankind in general, as well as Poets, who are Condemn'd to Traffick with all sort of Humours, and to be oblig'd to such as will own themselves pleas'd, with what they like. A Fatigue, which I can the better bear, because it offends me little, which way soever it happens, always believing, that, next diverting my Friends, to please my Self, is the best-method; but as my Friends satisfaction takes Place first, I hope this Comedy will not appear distastful to 'em, especially to you, being Corrected, And My Lord, thus Humbly Dedicated, By

closer.signed: Your Lordships most Obliged, And Humble Servant, D'VRFEY.

div.head: Dramatis Personae.

list.label: Cocklebrain. A half-witted Country-Gentleman, whom his Wife rules, and keeps in Town spending his Estate at Basset; yet still bubbles him in hopes of Preferment.
Justice Grub. An old Peevish Country Justice, an hater of the Town, and its Fashions
Lyonel. A Well Bred Ingenious Gentleman: who, being hindred of his Mistress, by the King, fell distracted.
Clermont. Longevile Bewford. Basset-Players and Agents with Aurelia, in the Bubling her Husband.
list.item: Mr. Kinaston. Mr. Powel. Mr. Bowman.
list.label: Toby. Servant to Cocklebrain, a sly Drolling Fellow that hates the Town, and his Master's living there.
Sir Iasper Lost-all. A foolish Knight, that has lost all his Estate at Basset.
Fleaflint. Sharpe. Two Rooks at Basset. Usher of the Black Rod.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.label: Aurelia, Wife to Cocklebrain, a Town-bred Jilt, a great Basset-player.
Celia, A Maid of Honour.
Maria, Woman to Aurelia. Doctor, Citizens, Barber, Dancers, and Attendants.

div.p: SCENE, The COURT, in the Reign of Henry the Fourth.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: A Poets Trade, like Hazard, does entice;
He's the unlucky Caster, you the Dice.
Constant ill Luck attends at every Throw
You Criticks are like Fullhams, high and low,
Yet 'tis his Fate, he can't give over so.
Like a young Wife, just ready to Lie in,
That whines and cries, Ile ne're come to't agen:
When th' danger's past, and pains forgotten all,
Her Heart's not broke, She'l venture 'tother Squawl.
To all new Plays, like Towns besieg'd, you come,
And each pert husfing Whipster throws a Bomb,
Whilst th' trembling Author all the Shot retains
Of several Nations, and their several Brains;
'Tis strange, you Beaux at home should do such harm,
Pray find another Buda, if you'l Storm;
One good sound Battel would some Thought provoke;
For Brains are never seen, till Heads are broke;
From Famous Fletcher's Hint, this piece was made,
All Mirth and Droll, not one reflection said.
For now-a-days poor Satyr hides his Head.
No wholsom Ierk dares lash fantastick Youth,
You wits grow angry, if you hear the Truth,
Old Fumble now, may at Doll Commons strip,
Without being flagn'd by a Poetick Whip.
The Noble Peer may to the Play repair,
Court the pert Damsel with her China Ware.
Not Marry her, if he please, no one will care.
The Whore too may with Quality be Box'd,
And set up for a Virtue, though She's Pox'd.
The Fop in Love may his dull Genius try;
The Soldier Drink, so Quarrel, and so Dye.
The Alderman may Cheat, the Lawyer Lye.
And Satyr now not dare to question, why;
You shall scape too, at th' Trading end o'th' Town,
Your Wit sticks fast, although your Charter's gone;
Therefore brave Knights o'th' Apron, and the Yard,
All fear of a Satyrick Iest discard;
Let not this Play, through your shrewd censure, fall,
And then cheat on, and prosper great and small,
You shall have Liberty of Conscience, All.

div.head: THE Fool's Preferment; OR, THE THREE DUKES OF DUNSTABLE.
SCENE I.
div.stage: A Garden, discovering Lyonel crown'd with Flowers, and Antickly drest, sitting on a Green Bank.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: YOnder he is: Oh that Heart-breaking Object,
The Darling of the Times, his Country's honor,
Our Sexes Joy, and Glory of his own,
That was all Bravery, All Wit, All Merit,
Wild as the Winds; lies there bereft of Sense;
Whilst here I mourn, that am the Fatal Cause.
Fall, Fall, ye Tears! and throbb, unhappy Heart!
That, in a luckless Hour, refus'd such Love;
Threatned by Friends, and forc'd by Royal Power.
I threw a Dearer, Brighter Jewel from me,
Than e'er deckt Woman's Beauty.
Oh wou'd to Heaven,
That I had known the Curse of stubborn Will,
Or I had dy'd e'er I had done such Ill.

q.l: I sigh'd, and I pin'd,
Was Constant and Kind
To a Iilt that laugh'd at my Pains:
Though my Passion ne'r cool'd,
I found I was fool'd,
For all my Abundance of Brains.
But now I'm a Thing
As great as a King:
So blest is the Head that is addle!
The dull, empty Pate
Soonest comes to be great:
Fate doats on a Fool in the Cradle.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Ay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: How goes the World? From thence the Zodiack, the Sun, the Moon and Planets; In what Meridian are we?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Do but hear me, Sir!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: With all my Heart. I know your Cleft Sex are in great Trust with Lucifer: and can do a man a Favour; a handsome Woman is the Devil's Soul-Broker, a Place worth ten of his Gentleman-Usher; you shall find I have Court Breeding. Come, pronounce.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Sir, I am come.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: From the Dread Soveraign King; I know it well: I am all Duty, all Courtier, all Cringe; as supple as my Ladies Page; he is a Gracious Prince, Long may he live. Belong you to his Chamber?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Not I indeed, Sir, that Place is not for Women!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Not for Women!— What Place more fit for Women than a Chamber? They were begot in Chambers! Born in Chambers! Dress'd in Chambers! And if you take a Woman out of her Chamber, you'll find her good for nothing—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: For nothing, Sir! Can you say so of me? D' you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Most exquisitely.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: What is my Name?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: The Gossips call'd you first Phillissida, because of your little Mouth, and narrow Gaskins: but you are pust out like a Pumpkin since, Hell Gate's not wider than a Woman's Conscience.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Fye, Sir, All this to her that loves you!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Love me, nay, that's a Lye! I had but one Love, and her the good King Henry has taken from me, to bribe his Favorite for his Legs and Cringes. But hush— no more of that; I must be wary, Pitchers have Ears. Some one may call this Treason.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: That Favourite, Sir, is now in great Disgrace; And the King pitying you, has sent me hither.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: To soak me like a Spunge: Drain all my Secrets, and then hang me up. Ha, I find it out: This Woman here is sent to undermine me; to buz Love into me: to try my Spirits, and make me open and betray my self: Hah, Is not this true?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir— Heaven knows I love you too well to betray you! Weeps.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Such was the Heavenly Musick of her Voice,
Soft as the Flute-like Sounds that charm'd my Ear,
When my dear Celia lov'd me, but she's gone:
The Fiend Ambition bears her on his Wings:
She mounts, she soars, and leaves her Vows behind her.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Oh my Curst Fortune!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Do you weep, let me see? Pray let me taste your Tears. Ha, ha, ha, ha, Rose Water by this Light: Nine pence a Pint, sold at the Pothecaries: Oh thou Dissembler! that is, Thou very Woman: All thy Sex carry perpetual Fountains in their Heads, and make their Eyes spout Mischiefs when they please.

q.l: There's nothing so fatal as Woman,
To hurry a Man to his Grave;
You may think, you may plot,
You may sigh like a Sot:
She uses you more like a Slave.
But a Bottle, altho' it be common,
The Cheats of the Fair will undo,
It will drive from your Head
The Delights of the Bed;
He that's drunk is not able to wooe. Ex. Lyon.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Method in Madness, Grace even in Distraction:
I'll never leave him, 'till, by Art or Prayer,
I have restor'd his Senses to their Office.
Oh most unnatural Vice in silly Women!
We oft refuse what best deserves our Love,
And often chuse the contrary!—
Thus Shadow-like, we make the Sentence true,
Follow'd we fly: but if they fly, pursue.
I that this Sun of Vertue could not see,
When long his Beams were hourly cast on me:
Like blushing Flowers wanton'd when I shone,
But ne'er his Value knew till he was gone:
Unhappy Sex! Thy Fortune never drew
So great a Blessing as a Love that's true,
But to be sold by Friends, by Coxcombs griev'd;
Match'd for thy Plague: and born to be deceiv'd. Ex. Celia.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Sirra, Sirra! I say once more, The Court's a Glorious Place, and I am much honour'd with the Society of my Wives Noble Friends there. Therefore leave off your grumbling, and let me have no more of your mouldy Advice, or as I am a true Courtier, and consequently a Wit—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Wit! No, no, Sir, you are Iohn Cockle-brain, of Plowden-Hicket, in the Country of Staffordshire, Esquire.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: A Squire, which is as much as to say a Fool; is it? Very well, Sirra.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why the Devil will you be a Wit, Sir, you had as good own your self a Bastard: For there has not been Wit in your Family since the Conquest.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Sirra, if I am a Wit, I will be a Wit, and let my Family rise and deny it if they dare; But whatsoever I am, Sirra, I am sure you are an Impudent Rascal; and don't you think, Sirra, because you found me with a Whore t'other Day at Green-Goose-Fair, when I was drunk, and I desir'd you not to tell my Wife; that I'll bear every Flirt from you. The World would be finely govern'd indeed, if every Man's Servant, because he is a Pimp, must pretend to be sawcy.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And shall we never go into the Country agen then, Sir? Will you run out all your Estate here, for this confounded Name of a Courtier?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Sirra, You sawcy Rascal, 'tis a Name that draws Wonder and Duty from all Eyes and Knees.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ay, 'Twill draw your Worship's Land within the walls too, where you may have it, all inclos'd and sure: Oh, here comes your Country Uncle, Old Justice Grub, he'll grub you now i' faith; he'll firk you for your Feathers and your Fooleries. He has had no Drink but Juice of Crabs and Vinegar this week, to fit him for you. He'll make you a Courtier. Enter Grub.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Good morrow, good morrow, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Good morrow, Cod'shead: Cockle-brain and Cod'shead are much at one. Own'z! dost wear that damn'd Cap upon thy Head with a Summer-fly Flap, like the Fore-Horse of a Waggon? And dost thou bid me good morrow? Why, you Ninny, you Nicompoop, you Noun Adjective, for thou canst not stand by thy self, I am sure; must my Family be disgrac'd and ruin'd by a flanting Fopdoodle, that is too finical to learn any Sense. A Pox on thee, I am asham'd on thee.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ay there, there, Sir, there's a Courtier for you.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why, good Uncle, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p:
Gadzooks. What's the matter? why, you Scatterbrain!
you Son of a Whore; and yet I think my Sister was honest: What's the matter? Why thou'rt undone. Thou art lost. I would not lend thee Two pence on thy Land: Thou art a meer Bankrupt.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Very well! Very fine indeed: this is but the first Course. I'll leave you together and go and laugh. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Not too fast, not too fast, Uncle: Pray consider a little.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Not a Jot, Faith! What dost thou do at Court but to be ruin'd? Hast reckon'd up thy Income? Dost thou know the Value of thy Tenants Sweat and Labour, and thy Expences here?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I think I do.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Think, nay, that's a Lye: thou hast not thought these seven Years, to my knowledge. Thou hast a Wife, a handsome Wife, Men say: Canst thou pretend to have a Grain of Thought, And yet bring her to Court? Ah— grins.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what ill can she get there?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: A Bastard, Sir, it may be, to inherit your Estate. Ownz! I shall ne'er have Patience!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Oh Sir, you are Splenetick!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: You are a Jack pudding, A Pragmatick Spend-thrift, A Fellow that I would beat into a Powder, if I had the Law on my side. Can there come any thing of Essences, Pulvilio's, and Perfumes, more than the Head-Ach? Take your Wife to task, ye Blockhead, and Thrum her Jacquet well, she'll ne'er be good else; She's of the right Strain, I know her to a hair; and if thou wouldst be Famous, beat thy self, for thou deserv'st it richly.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: What your froward Gall can vent on me I bear, but if you rail against my Wife—

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why you shall know that I am a Fighter.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: A Fool: That fair 1200 l. a Year will shrink into a Tester, by next Summer, and all to be a Courtier, in the Devil's Name.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Well, Sir: And is not that enough?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p:
You Dogbolt, Enough! Will that Frothy Title keep firm your Credit, Sir? Will your Spindle. Shanks there e'er carry
you to win the Goal of Honour? They look already as they could scarce drag thee over the Kennel, with a Pox to you, good Mr. Courtier.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I am a Courtier, and intend to be a Cherubin. Courtiers are all Cherubins and Seraphims; and I think I have some Reason.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: How, Reason! I have seen a Dapper thing more like a Courtier, set up to scare the Crows out of the Corn.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Much good may't do your Heart, Uncle, you are merry, and I could entertain you with a Joke against your Countrey Life, were I so dispos'd; your Ditches and your Dunghils. I could nettle you i' faith.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Ye Jackanapes, Gadzooks! Speak a word more against the Countrey and I'll beat thee, I'll swinge thee, before thy Wife and all thy Family: I will i' faith, therefore don't provoke me!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Nay, Why so angry; Uncle? I pass by your Lowing of Cows, Bleating of Sheep, and your damn'd Noise of Chattering Rooks in the Morning, that would not let one sleep. You see I am patient.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Rooks! There's ne'er a Fop at Court has half their Sense, to my knowledge, No, nor their Harmony: The finest Vocal Musick in the World, this Fool calls Chattering. Ah, thou art a Dunce. I had rather hear a Rook sing than Si Fachi.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Nor do I rally on your fine Discourse, which is commonly about your Dogs and Horses; and for your part, Uncle, you have a Passion for your Wall Ey'd Mare, exceeds the Love of Women.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Here's an impudent Rascal, here's a Rogue, to debauch my Darling-Mare before my Face. And the Dog knows too I love her as well as I do my Wife. Why, you slanderous Villain! Now could I even weep for Madness: Sirra, leave your Prating, or provide your self a Second. Gad— I'll fight for the Honour of my Mare, sooner than for any Lady at Court by th' half.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I have done, good Uncle.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: 'Tis well you have, Sir: Wall Ey'd Mare, you Puppy! 'Tis true she's queer of an Ogle or so; But what then? Look you into the Park, or into your Damn'd Play house, and see what Crowds of Female Sins come thither, and then let's hear you prate.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: But, Uncle, why are you so inveterate against the Court? Were you ever there?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Not I, thank Heaven: I got down t' other day as far as Charing-Cross, and had like to have been choak'd at that distance.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Come, come, Uncle! Leave off your snarling, and ridiculous Anger, and bring your Wife to Court. I hear she's handsome: let her not live there to be a Farmer's blowing; and be confin'd to Serge with Silver Edging; and Petticoats far coarser than my Horse-Cloath: But give her Velvets, Tissues, Pearls, and Jewels.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: A Coach and Usher, and two running Footmen, and I will send my Wife to give her Rules.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: 's Heart! I had rather send her to Virginia, and make her plant Tabaco. This Fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Sirra, How slept your Mistress? and what Visitants are come this Morning?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, as I came out, two Lords were newly entred.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: This is great now, do any Lords, Uncle, come to see your new Wife?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: No. Lord have Mercy upon her if they did: Heaven keep my Wife, and all my Issue Female still from their Lordships.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Oh, you are dull and pall'd! You have no Pallat.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: This Fellow's a Cuckold too, a rank Cuckold! I smell him: well, God b'w'y': thou art a rare Coxcomb, and I'll not see thy Folly any longer. When you want Money, Friend, for a new Fund of Prodigality, I suppose, I shall hear of you; but not a Penny: let thy own Folly feed thee. Ownz! To be a Cuckold too, that plagues me most of all— Ah you senceless Ass! Gad! I have a great mind to take the Dog cross the Face; A Cuckoldly Rogue. Gadzooks! If I stay I shall murder him. Ex. in anger.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: A strange dull angry old Fellow this: But just such another Piece to Dirt was I, before my Eyes were open'd by my Wife.

div.p: Oh, here she comes: Good morrow, Dearest.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Good morrow, my Jewel. Thou look'st well this Morning.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Thank thee, Sweet Heart: I have no other reason.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I am glad on't: Now, then to my present business, which is Money.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Faith, I have none left.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I hope you will not say so: nor imagine so base and low a Thought: I have none left! Are these words fitting for a Man of Honour, and Dignity that shall be.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: The Lord knows when: Thou hast been seven Years about it, and yet I am where I was, Child. But I know thou hast daily and nightly labour'd with thy Friends for my Advancement.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Very well, Sir: And do you pop me off with this slight Answer, i' faith I have none left? i' faith you must have!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I must have!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You must have. Nay, stare not, Sir; 'tis true, I must have Money: for be perswaded, if we fall now, or be but seen to shrink under our fair Beginnings, 'tis our Ruine, and then good night to all, but our Disgraces.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why, where's the Hundred Pound I gave you yesterday.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Oh that! I lost it at Basset, last night.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Then you may win it at Basset this morning: Why, can you think, Wife, I'll endure such Doings? Why, how the Devil could you lose all that?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I had horrid Luck, Child: Come, I'll tell thee how. Dost understand the Game, Hony?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Not I: I understand none of the Game: A Pox o' the Game, if this be the Fruits on't.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Not understand it! Well, I am resolv'd I'll teach it thee. 'Tis the most Courtly, the most Grand, the most Graceful Game. And has the finest Terms in't that e'er were heard: As thus now! First, there's the Fasse, then the Alpieu, or Paroli,
the Sept & le va, Quinze. & le va, Trent. & le va, Sonicà, nay sometimes the Soisant & le va.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Soisant, and the Devil and all: Why this is Conjuring, Confound it— What a damn'd Game's here, to lose a 100 l. at!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I tell thee, Child, I had the worst Luck in the whole World: I lost a Sept & le va upon an Eight King.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Gadzooks! And wilt lose a King's Revenue at this rate. This is a Game that's fit for none but Kings and Queens, to play at, for ought that I see.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Ay. 'Tis a Royal Game, indeed; but prithee do but observe my ill Fortune! I was Fass'd every Card, I set, or when I drew a lucky one it did not go. I had lost seven Kings before, and made a Sept & le va upon an Eight: When to see the Prodigy of ill Luck, A Citt, a strange Punt, that sat next me, a pert forward pushing Fellow follow'd the winning Knaves, and won a Quinze & le va before ever I could make an Alpieu: But what vext me most intolerably, was to see my Fat Lady Thump Cushion make Paroli, and then a Sept & le va upon the same Card, and when I lost my King four times in one Deal, she, upon a filthy Knave, every time won Sonicà.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: The Devil take my Lady's Sonica, and my Lord's too; What a Noise is here with 'em?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I think never poor Punt was so Embarrass'd: but I have done: Come, now what say'st thou to this Money? I'll soon fetch up my Losses, Sweet Heart: I must have, let me see 500 l. by to morrow night: nay, ne'er flinch at it; 'Tis for thy Preferment, thou know'st.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Nay, faith, I know not what to say to't: 'tis such a Devillish hard World, that my Tennants write me word they are all running away. The last 50 l. I laid down for your tall Cousin's Horse and Equipage: He that's going to be an Officer; And I han t a ragg more left, as I am a true Courtier.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir, have you no Land in the Country?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why, yes, but I had forgot that.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
It must be remembred: some of it must fetch this Money: Thou shalt not lose Preferment, my Dear, for the sake of a few dirty Acres; Especially when, by my means, the Sun of
Honour is just going to break out upon thee. Dost hear, Child? This Land must be in London by to morrow Night.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Well, well, if it must, it must: What, 300 Acres will serve the Turn? Hum!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Twill do very well: And now you speak like a Man, and like a Courtier that shall be great, and suddenly; I have said it: Well, adieu! you'll dispatch; I must go get the BassetCards ready; for I expect my Lord's Company, and all the Punts here after Dinner: Mr. Winnall Taillies, and I am to be his Croupier: If I want Money I'll make shift to borrow out of my Lord's Fobb.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Well, well, prithee borrow what thou wilt out of my Lord's Fobb. Go, leave me a little.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Adieu, Child, Adieu, my Pretious. Claps his Cheek, & ex.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: 'Tis a good natur'd ingenious Devil; and does so bustle about the Courtiers to make me great, and is so caress'd by this Lord, and by t'other Knight, that 'twould do ones Heart good to see her: that's the truth on't, she must have this Money; but how to make this Sale handsomely now, let me see! Gad, I am almost afraid to tell my Man Toby on't, 'twill break the poor Fellow's Heart, to hear that I am going to sell: but hang't, it must be done, and there's no more to be said. Who's within there? Toby.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Did you call, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Ay, honest Toby, I would have you run presently to the Exchange, and there to Sir Iohn Cutchinele, the Merchant, offer 300 Acres of my Land: Why dost thou stare so?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why faith, Sir, see how strangely things will happen, I dream't last night that you were in Bedlam, and now my Dream is out.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Oh spare your Wit, good Toby, for your Business, Tell him, d'ye hear? 'Tis choice and fertil, and ask upon't 500 l.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Sir, do not do this; pray take my Cap and consider a little: This honest Land, that you are parting with, hath been true to you, and done you loyal Service.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: As 'twas in Duty bound: But whatever happens, my Wife must not want Money: for if she do, either she or her Friends, I may whistle for Preferment. Go, go, begone, I say, and when you come back— look for me in the Presence. Exit Cockl.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: 'Tis this damn'd Wife that is the Cause of all, and this, Oh this is the dear Marriage Blessing; Man is the Shuttle, and his Wife the Loom; and so they weave themselves into a Knot, that when 'tis done, they'd hang themselves to unty: I'll to his Uncle presently, and tell him all, perhaps 'twill stop his Journey, and make him come and rail, and beat my Mistress: I'd give my Wages to see't done handsomely: I'll whet him I am resolved. Exit.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: There's no good to be done upon this Fool, my Kinsman, so I'll into the Country, presently, and leave him to the Fool's Whip, Misery. Let me see— I may recover 20 Miles to night. Ho! Within there— Some body call a Barber; I'll be shav'd first, however: I shall ride so much the lighter. Call a Barber, there. Enter Lyonel. How now! Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Sir, I have follow'd you in here.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: So methinks, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: 'Pray what may I call your Name?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: My Name? Why my Name is Grub, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Grub! right: you are a Mahometan.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: The Devil I am.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: I know it; but am secret: Of what Faction are you? What Party join you with?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p:
Prithee, I know no Factions, nor Parties, not I: I am a plain Countrey Gentleman, and am just going out of
Town. What, a Devil, does the Man mean?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Then wear this Cross of White, and where you see the like, they are my Friends: observe 'em well, the Time is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I'll wear none of your Cross, not I: I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Not know my meaning! you may spare your Cunning, Sir, you can pick nothing out of this: this Cross is nothing but a Cross, a very Cross: plain, without Spell or Witch craft; search it; you may suspect Poison, Powder, or Wild-fire; but you are mistaken.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I see 'tis a plain Cross, what then? What a Plague, is this Fellow?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Then do your worst: I care not. Tell the King, as I am sure you will, of all my Actions: and so God save His Majesty. This is no Treason. Exit.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Tell the King! What a strange, odd, whimsical Rogue is this! But this Town is full of nothing else: Nothing but Fools and Madmen throng the Streets. I'll get out on't as soon as I can. Come, where's the Barber?

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.p: Here, here, Ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Come, come, away with't quickly: but, d'ye hear, Sirra? Ha'n't you got the Itch now, which your Town-Breeding would complement upon my Face? Let's see your Fingers.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Oh Clear, clear, as a Sucking Infant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: A smooth-fac'd Rogue: Sirra, you are a Whore-Master.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: A little given that way, Sir; but I want Money.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Alas, poor Fellow! 'tis great Pity, faith. Claps his Cheek.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: If I were a great Man, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: You would keep a Whore, and starve your Wife, as they do.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Very well: Ha, ha, ha. I have not met with a more honest Fellow: a good handsome, sleek Rascal too! How many Bastards have you, Friend? Claps his Cheek.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Not very many, Sir. I have only two at Nurse, and another a coming— Will your Worship be pleased to give me an old Shirt?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: No, you Dog; I have a Kid of my own in the Countrey, that must be serv'd first. But, my bonny Shaver, you get your Living honestly, I hope? You are not given to Thieving?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: To no Burglaries, Sir, they are troublesome; But for the neat Conveyance of a Hand into a Pocket, or so.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Hum! 'Tis as I said. Thieves, Fools and Madmen over-run this plaguy Town— Would I were well a Horse-back.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh Sir, undone, undone, all lost, ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: How now? What's the Matter? What is there a Fire? ha! Who's there, Toby?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, Sir, poor Toby, undone, utterly undone.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Be undone, and be hang'd! what, a Devil, dost fright me about it?— Pox— I thought the Town had been a Fire.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Sir, If ever you had any Respect for the Antient Family of the Cockle-brains, to which that of the Grubs is Worshipfully join'd, turn back to our House, and beat my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Prithee, beat her thy self, and be hang'd, if thou hast a mind to't.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: 's Bud. Would I might, I'd strap her with a Vengeance— Besides my Master is undone, unless you go, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I'll not come near him, an extravagant Rascal, he has not a peny of Money; and I warrant his Land will be going e'er long.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: 'Tis going, Sir, 'tis going now.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: What's that? Is he going to Mortgage?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: To sell, Sir, to sell— 300 Acres are doom'd this night, unless you stop it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Give me my Hat and Gloves. Starts off his Chair.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: What is't you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: 300 Acres! Oh intolerable Rogue! I'll be with him: Gadzooks!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Why, Sir, your Beard is not half off.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Pox o' my Beard. I'll go with half a Nose to save 300 Acres. Come along, Toby— Gad I'll thrash him into Stubble, but I'll change him, I am resolv'd on't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Good Luck be with thee, I ne'er had till now Half so much cause to bid God speed the Plough. Exit.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Discovers the Basset-Table; Aurelia, Clermont, Longoville, Bewford, and other Gentlemen and Ladies sitting round at Play, Winnall is dealing; several are standing by, and others walking about; Acting the several Humours of Winners and Losers.

sp.speaker: Sharpe.
sp.p: WELL! What Times, Flea-flint? What purchase to night? What Rate bears Money? Hah!

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: Pox, not worth a Man's trouble: I have lent but Three Eight and forties yet.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: But you'll draw so many Fifties, I hope!

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: Yes, certainly, I should hardly wait here else: there's no Pawn stirring neither; not so much as a Table-Diamond, nor my Lady's Locket, the Devil's in't! I think, this Trade will hardly find a Man Salt to his Radishes; Prithee, what News about Town, Ned?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Why young Lyonel, they say, is mad.

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: Mad! Prithee for what?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: It seems the King once parted him and his Mistress, who was a rich Orphan, intending to bestow her on his Favourite; Grief for which Chance and her Inconstancy has since that time much distracted him, and now in his mad Fit, he conceits the King designs to hang him, and trap him speaking Treason.

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: Alas, poor Lyonel! Mad! and mad for Love too! Thou art a Miracle indeed.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: What Lady's that?

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: Sir Iasper Lost-alls's Lady, one that's so much in Love with her Coach that she's hardly ever out on't: prithee let's observe 'em; I find, by his fidgetting about, the Bank has stript him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, Sir Iasper, I have told you of this a hundred times, pray come away now, I find your Money's all gone, by that sheepish Look of yours. D'ye hear? Pray let some body order my Coach to come to the Door. You'll never leave this Basset, Sir Iasper, till you have ruin'd me. My Coach and Horses there, quickly. Come, I protest, I'm quite tir'd with coming up Stairs. To a Footman.

sp.speaker: Sir Iasp.
sp.p: Gad, Madam, to tell you the truth, I have lost your Coach and Horses since you went.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Lost my Coach and Horses!

sp.speaker: Sir Iasp.
sp.p: Yes, faith, you must e'en beat home upon the Hoof, there's no Remedy?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, Thou Monster! thou darest not, sure, put such an Affront upon a Woman of my Quality; one that—

sp.speaker: Sir Iasp.
sp.p: One that shall scold with any Woman of Quality in Town, I'll say that for her, but I'll not stay to hear more on't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Oh intolerable! Was there ever such a Brute seen! that whilst I was paying an innocent Visit to my Cousin Doll Feetly here in the House, could have the Barbarity to lose my dear Coach and Horses, without which, alas! what is a Lady? How can a Lady subsist without her Coach and Horses? A Husband! A Clown; A Beast: one I married and got Knighted to have Comfort
of him, and now the Brute, to reward me, has lost my dear Coach and Horses at filthy Basset, the Devil take him, how does the Monster think, a Lady dress'd in a Gown, as I am, shall foot it Home now? Takes up her Train, & discovers her Stockings down, Shoes tatter'd, & Exit.

sp.speaker: Flea. Sharp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, this was pleasant enough.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Tre winns, Six loses, Knave winns, Ten loses, Eight winns— Madam, you lose the King. to Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: A Curse on all ill Luck; Fass'd so many times, a Paroli, Sept, and Quinze & le va lost in a Moment Tearing the Cards.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Plgue on't, I am stript too, and this is all the Treasure I have left in this World. Kissing her Hand.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well, Sir, do not you complain till you lose that Treasure, I shall wheedle my Husband and get Flush again within few hours, and then, Sir, perhaps you may hear from me; in the mean time Good Morrow, 'tis almost Sun-rising, I'le to Bed now. Ex. smiling.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: She gives me the Ougle to follow her. Oh this damn'd Itch of Play, yet cannot I give over, if I were to be hang'd. Flea-flint, Prithee come hither.

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: What's your Pleasure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Thou know'st, I have always been thy Friend, and given thee Barratto freely, Prithee lend me another Eight and forty upon Honour.

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: Not without a Pawn, Sir, I have sworn the contrary.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: As I am a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: As I am a Man of Honour, Sir, I must not break my Oath.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Thou wilt not do me this Courtesie then.

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: I cannot, Sir, what, would you have me damn my self for a Trifle: if you have e're a Pawn?—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Ile give thee Bond and Judgment.

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: Pish, Paper, Paper, I'le do nothing without a Pawn, I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Well, come hither, thou shalt have a Pawn.

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: Where, what is't?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: And such a Pawn, as never was propos'd to Man before.— thou saw'st that Lady that went out?

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and what of her?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: She is my Mistress, and the dearest Jewel that e're unlucky Gamester pawn'd before: One, that I value equal with my Life; yet such a Witchery there is in Play, that for this Money, I'le contrive it so, that thou shalt be Caress'd instead of me, till I return what's lent.

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: This I confess is the strangest Pawn I ever heard of, but I lend no Money upon Faces, Sir, I must beg your Pardon: However I shall make bold to tell the Lady, what a Faithful Spark she has. Aside.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Dog, Rook, Rascal! What a Slave was I to offer such an inestimable Treasure! Sirra, get you gone, or I'll cut your Pate.

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.p: Ay, Ay; Rail, rail! Ha, ha, ha. Ex. Flea flint.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Clear'd— stript: by this Light, not a Rag left. tears the Cards.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I won two Hundred Guineas: What's the matter, Iack?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, a Pox on him, come, Prithee let's go, and beat up the Rogues at the Blue-Posts, for a quart of burnt Sherry.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: With all my heart, a Plague of this damn'd Basset-Table. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Do but see, Sir, they're at it still, at this time o'th' Morning.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Oons speak to 'em, souse in upon 'em, Nephew.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: No, pray, Uncle, do you, for my part I'm asham'd.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Gad, and so I will, what's here to do, what a Pox de'e make an Ordinary of my Nephew's House? a Bawdy-House were a better Name by the half, nothing but Cheating, and Gaming, and Roaring, and Tearing, Gad-sookers, 'tis past Suffering, and as I am his Friend, and Uncle—

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: How now, who have we here, Sir, will you venture Fifty Pieces, here's a Stool.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: And there 'tis at your Head, Dogbolt. Draw, Nephew, draw, Toby, draw, draw, we'le Basset the Rogues.

div.stage: Enter Lyonel, with a Helmet on, and Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: What's here, Treason going forward, I'le make one against ye, Faith. First attacks Grub, and has him down, then throws the Cards about, and falls upon the Gamesters, till Grub rises, and they then beat Lyonel and all out.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: So, so, now lock the Door upon 'm Toby

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Bravely fought, i'faith, why, Uncle, you beat the Mad-man too, you fought like Scanderbeg; you are not hurt, I hope—

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: No, hang 'em, they are all Polltroons, Rogues that have no more Souls in 'em than so many Fleas, therefore hear me once more, and mark me well: If thou dost not instantly break this damn'd Custom, and make thy Wife know her self, Ill desert thee for ever, never see thy Face, but leave thee to ensuing Rags and Poverty, a thing not worthy for the Dogs to piss upon

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ne're think to see honest Toby again neither, I'me too proud of my Parts, to serve a Beggar, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Cockle.
sp.p: Do you really think my Wife deceives me then?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: 'sbud, think it, 'tis past thinking, for I know it.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Sir, she came Home at three a Clock yesterday Morning, and was led up Stairs between two Thundring Whoremasters, one had a great Patch on's Nose, you may guess by what, and there they were two Hours in her Chamber: What they did there, the Lord knows.

sp.speaker: Cockle.
sp.p: 'Tis likely, they were Plotting my Preferment.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Plotting to make thee a Cuckold, that's your Preferment.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And a Beggar most certainly.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: For she knows no End in Lavishing.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And for Eating and Drinking, she's the very Devil, her Belly is a meer Parson's Barn, all your Tenants pay Tyth to't, and yet 'tis never satisfyed.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: The Truth is, she has been given to take a Cup, of late.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: A Cup, 'ds Heart I have seen her as Maudlin as a Midwife at a Crying out.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And when she's in her Beer, she's wondrous Chast; No doubt.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Come, come, once more I say send for her, for my Part, I shall have no Patience if I see her: send for her I say, and pack her into the Country, instantly, or never see my Face more.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Well, Sir, your Hearty Love, and Reasons have prevail'd, it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: It shall?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Yes▪ Sir, it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Why, that's well said, Gad, I'le slap thee down another Hundred Pounds in my Will for this, and let Wives know their Duty.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: She has lost a Plaguey deal of Mony lately, at this damn'd Basset, that's the Truth on't.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: A Mint, a Mint, the Devil and all, I know it, for 'tis a greater Cheat, than the Lottery; 'tis just like giving a man twenty Pounds. to let you lose 100.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: But she shall have no more, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Thou'rt in the right, Boy, it makes 'em Wild and Wanton. I make my young Jade at home leap at a Crook'd Nine-pence: give a Wife Money, give her a Pudding.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Mine has had the Indies.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Ay, Iacky, thou hadst better have sent her thither by Half, take heed for the future, now hold fast, and prosper, I'll presently take Horse, and tell thy Tenants such a Story; this will be joyful News at Plowden, farewel, good Iacky, be but resolute, and then the Devil, I mean, thy Wife will have no Power over thee.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Blessings go along with ye, Sir, you have made me a New-Man too.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Farewel, Honest To. I shall see thee in the Country shortly, now little To. where we'le crack a Flagon, and roast Apples, ye Rogue. Farewel. Nephew, God-b'w'y'. To, your most humble Servant, good Nephew— Come, my Horse, my Horse there. Exit Grub.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Good Journey to'e, Sir, I'll be with ye to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oons I could leap for Joy, this is the happiest Day.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Go, Toby, and call your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: But shall she not prevail, Sir, and out-talk ye— as she us'd to do? For you know she has a plaguy Tongue.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I'll not hear her, but rail at her till I am ten Miles off.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: If you are forty, so much the better, Sir, for she's so shrill, that, if the Wind sit right, she'll sound from hence to Barnet.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Go, go, call her hither.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I could leap out of my Skin, my Heart's so light, a Plague o' this stinking Town! now we shall get a little Air, and go a Hunting, and a Fishing agen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why, what a thing was I, that such a Creature as a Wife could rule me? Do not I know that Woman first was made for Man's Diversion: she shall know now, a thing that few— do, She has a Husband that can govern her.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: She's coming, Sir, and in a Plaguy Fret. Stand upon your Guard, Sir.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What Planet reigns? or what mad Whimsey have you now i'th' Head, that makes you call me from my Rest, that know I have not been in Bed all Night?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Oh, you shall go to Bed betimes hereafter, and shall be rais'd again at thrifty Hours.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What does he mean!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p:
I'll have no more of your Court Tricks, your Honours, your Offices, and all your large Preferments I'll be content to lose: for, to be plain w'ye,
I now at last begin to smell a Rat,
And understand too late what you'd be at.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The Man is mad sure!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: The Woman would have him so; but it shall be a Country Madness then, for I'll be gone this Morning.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Very fine; and who's Advice is this, Sir, I beseech ye, your Swabber Toby's?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I shall have my Head broke, I see by her Looks.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: No one's Advice, good Wife, but my own Reason; therefore make ready.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sir, I hope you'll stay till the next Ball be past however.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Not I: I have been Balling on't too long, you have kept me here these seven Years a Balling, treating your Friends, and wasting all my Substance in Riot and Fine Cloaths, which was the way you told me to be preferr'd: but I find no such matter, therefore make ready, and in that Gown which you came first to Town in, your Grogram-Safe-guard and Hood suitable. Thus on a double Gelding shall you amble, and my Man Toby shall be set before ye.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Hem, hem, well said, Old Stiff Rump, i'faith, I begin to take Heart a little.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And will you go then in earnest?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Yes faith will I, and how dare you oppose my Will and Pleasure? Was not the Man ordain'd to rule his Wife?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: True, Sir, but where the Man does miss his way, it is the Woman's part to set him right; so Fathers have a right to guide their Sons in all their Courses, yet you oft have seen poor little Children that have both their Eyes lead their blind Fathers.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: She has a Plaguy Wit.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A devillish one, Sir, therefore take care of her, she'll talk ye mad else.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Come, come, you're but a little piece of Man.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But such a Piece as being taken away, what would Man do? The fairest, tallest Ship that ever sail'd, is by a little Piece of the same Wood steer'd right and turn'd about.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Ay, that's all one, you shall steer me no longer; I'll keep my Rudder in my own hand now.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Well said agen i'gad, a Plague, how the Jade lears now! Aside.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Tis your Clownish Uncle, I know, that hath put this into your Head, who is an Enemy to your Preferment, because I should not take place of his Wife; Come, by this Kiss, Sweet Heart, thou shalt not go.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: By this other Kiss, Sweet-heart, I will, and therefore on with your Trinkets; I know your Tricks. And if Preferment falls e're you are ready, 'tis welcome, else farewel to Court, i'Faith.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since you are resolv'd, I must obey.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: You must, therefore about it.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you must, you must, there's no more to be said.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Go, go, get ready. Women are pleasant things when once a Man begins to know himself.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But hark ye, Sir, because you use me thus, though I did look for present Honour this Morning for ye and at such an Hour, yet if it does not come e're I am ready, which I will be the sooner, left it should, when I am once set on a Countrey Life, not all the Power of Earth shall alter me, not all your Prayers, or Threats shall make me speak the least Word to my Honourable Friends, to do you any Grace.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And never more hope to be Honourable

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Not I, I have been tyr'd with hoping, if that be Court Preferment, I have enough on't.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nor to live greatly, you shall be so far from the Name of Honour, that you shall never see a Lord again.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why, what care I, if you had never seen one, I think your Honour had been ne're the worse for't.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But amongst Sheep and Oxen you shall live at home bespotted with your own lov'd Dirt, in nasty Cloaths, as you were us'd to do, and, to oblige you, I will live so too.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: And 'twill become ye well, come, the Day wears, therefore make hast, it shall be my Care to see your Stuff pack'd up— Toby— come. Exit Cockle.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir, here am I, Lord, how she looks now! Ex.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: It shall be my Care to gull you, my wise Husband. You shall stay, and more than that intreat me too, you shall have Honours presently. Who's there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Prithee, bring hither Pen, Ink, and Paper, quickly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis ready, Madam— what's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Your Master will not stay in Town, he says, unless Preferment fall within an Hour. Sits down, and writes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Let him command one of the City Gates, the Mobile are mutinying, or get him made a Constable, and walk the Rounds at Midnight, to catch Drunkards, any thing that has Hurry in't will please him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No, no, I have it for him, I have been prepar'd a good while for this Occasion: and when the World shall see what I have done, Let it not move the Spleen of any Wife, to see me make an Asse of my dear Husband. If they are Just, and know well how to use a Woman, then it were a Sin to wrong 'em, but when they grow conceited of themselves, and Ill performers, then shew 'em no Mercy. Here, Carry this Letter to young Clermont, and bid him and his Friends come hither instantly, and do as I have order'd there.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It shall be done, Madam. A Duce take him, I warrant he intends to pack us into the Country, to weed his Barley, or churn his Butter; but we'll churn him, and make Butter of his Brains first, here's that will fit him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: In the mean time, I'le go and dress my self,
In all the Country Cloaths, I us'd before,
Not to be gone, but make the Mirth the more. Ex. Aurelia.

div.stage: Re-enter Cockle-brain, and Toby, laden with Riding Equipage.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Is all pack'd up, Toby?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: All, all, Sir, there is no Tumbler runs through his Hoop, with more dexterity, than I about this Business, 'tis a Day, that I have long'd to see.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Come, where's my Boots? Sits down.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Here, here, Sir, and now y'are a made man.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Ay, Toby, now thou shalt know, I can command my Wife.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I am glad to see it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cockle.
sp.p: I do not love always to be made a Puppy, Toby.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: No, Sir, but yet methinks your Worship does not look right like a Country Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I will presently; give me my tother Hat—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: So, now my Jerkin.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: On with it, Toby, thou and I will live so finely in the Countrey, Toby, and have such pleasant Walks into the Woods, and then bring home Riding-Rods, and Walking-Staves.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And I will carry 'em, Sir, and sturdy Sticks for the Children.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: So thou shalt, and thou shalt do all, oversee my Work-folks, and at the Weeks End pay 'em all their Wages.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, if your Worship gives me Money.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Thou shalt eat Money, Man.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Beef, Beef, and't like your Worship: as for eating of Money, let that alone.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Give me my Trowzes, and I will make my Wife, thy Mistress, look to her Dairy well, and to her Landrey, that we may have our Linnen clean on Sundays.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And Holydays, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Ay, and e'er we walk about the Grounds provide our Breakfast, or she shall smoak; I'll make her a good Houswife; she now shall make no Journey to her Sisters, but live at home and feed her Poultrey fat, and see her Maids in Bed before her, and lock all the Doors.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Rare, rare, Sir, Why, this will be a Life for King and Queens.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Come, give me my Buff-Belt, and Hanger.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: 'Tis done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: So, this is as it should be; now, my Gloves.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Here they are, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: A Riding-Rod now, Come.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: There's nothing wanting, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: So, so, How dost thou like me now, hah?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Exceeding well, Sir; Now your Worship looks just like your self; A Man of Means and Credit; so did your wise and famous Ancestors ride up and down to Fairs to cheapen Cattle.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Go, hasten your Mistress, and make ready, I long to be on Horse-back.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I'll be ready in a Twinkling, Sir; never was Man so jocund; 'ds heart, I could dance all the way. Ex. Toby.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Who's that? Who's that, Friend?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I know not, Sir, I think it is my Master.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Who, he that walks in Gray, whisking his Riding-Rod?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: 'Tis he indeed, and at all Points prepar'd for his new Journey: Sirrah, when I wink upon ye, run out and tell the Gent. below, 'tis time.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Mr. Cockle-brain, Good Morrow t'ye.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: The same to you, Sir, this is one of my Wife's Court Friends; how simply he looks now, to see me in this Dress: My Wife's within, Sir, but she's busie.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: As she pleases, Sir; my Business is now with you.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: With me, Sir! Your Pleasure?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: 'Tis reported, Sir, I know not whether by some Enemy, malitiously, that envies your great Merit, and wou'd be ready to sow Discontents between his Majesty and you; or truly, which on my Faith I would be sorry for, that you intend in haste to leave the Court.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, within this half Hour. Toby.

sp.speaker: Tob. within.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Is my Wife ready?

sp.speaker: Tob. within.
sp.p: Presently, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: But, Sir, I needs must tell you, as a Friend, you should have taken your Journey privater; for 'tis already blaz'd about the Court.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I hope 'tis no Treason, is't?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Sir; but 'tis grown the common Talk: there's no News else, in Town; and in the Presence, all the Nobility and Gentry have nothing in their Mouths, but only this, That Mr. Cockle-brain, that Noble Courtier, is now departing hence: Every Man's Face looks ghastly on his Fellows; such a Sadness, before this day, I ne'er beheld at Court; Mens Hearts begin to fail 'em, when they hear it.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Sir, I had rather all their Hearts should fail 'em, than I stay here untill my Purse fail me.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: But yet you are a Subject; and beware, I charge you, by the Love I bear to you, how you do venture rashly on a Course to make your Soveraign jealous of your Deeds.
sp.l: For Princes Jealousies, where they love most,
Are quickly found, but they are hardly lost.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Sir, I know not what you mean by this! All the Love that I have found at Court, is, They have let me spend my Money there.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Have I not still profess'd my self your Friend?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Yes, yes. You have all profess'd, but you ne'er prov'd so yet.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Now, Sir, I will then; because I see you are wise, and give you thus much light into a Business, that came to me just now. Be resolute, stand stiffly to it, that you will be gone, and presently.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Troth, 'Tis what I intend.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: And, by this Light, you may be what you will. Will you be secret, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Ay. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: The King does fear you.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: And is now in Council about you.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: About me!

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: About you, Sir, I tell you; you will find he is in Council about you: his Councellours have told him all the Truth.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: What Truth have they told him?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Why, Sir, that which now he knows too well.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Too well! Prithee what is't? If any Rogue has sworn Treason against me now, I am in a fine Condition! Aside.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: That you have follow'd him these seven Years, with a great Train, and though he has not grac'd ye, yet you have div'd into the Hearts of thousands with Liberality and Noble Carriage: And if you should depart hence unpreferr'd, all discontented and seditious Spirits would flock to you, and thrust you into Action; with whose Help and your Tenants, if you were so dispos'd, who does know, how great a Part of this yet Peaceful Realm, you might make desolate: But when the King heard this!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: What said he?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: He sneez'd, and shook, as never Monarch shook'd before. And to be short, you may be what you will: but be not Ambitious, Sir, sit down with moderate Honours, lest you make your self more fear'd.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I know not what to think of this: his Looks are very serious.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: The Gudgeon bites. Oh, here comes Longoville.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Where's Mr. Cockle-brain?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: There, Sir, he stands: would you ought with him?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I should hardly sweat thus else. Good Morrow, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: His Majesty does recommend himself most kindly to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cockle.
sp.p: His Majesty?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and has, by me, sent you this Favour, kneel down, and rise a Knight.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: A Knight, Sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: A Knight, Sir, and he does farther request you, not to leave the Court so soon; for though your former Merits were neglected, after this time, there shall no Office fall, but you shall stand fair for't as any Man.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: What think you now, Sir? Hark you, a Word in your Ear: if you yield yet you are a Novice.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Do you think so? Softly aside.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Most certainly, therefore be resolute.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I understand you; a Knight, let me see; a Knight. Sir Iohn Cockle-brain! No: it won't do. Besides, I have known a Cheese-monger a Knight; a hundred Sniveling, addle-headed Citizens for Cheating, knighted: and Pimps and Cuckolds innumerable: No, no; I must go, I must desire his Majesty to excuse me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I'll bear your Knightly Words straight to the King, and send his Princely Answer back again. Ex. Longo.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Very well done, Sir, stand out stiffly, a while, 'twill be the better: I know there is a Tide of Honours coming.

sp.speaker: Cockle.
sp.p: But with my stiff Standing, if I should lose my Knighthood, I should wish I had been more limber.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Oh, never fear, Sir, 'tis impossible: Hark, there's a Noise below: 's Death, here's my Lord what de'e call him: pull down your Hat over your Eyes, look Grave and Sullen. So, so.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.p: Where is this new made Knight?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Hem, hem; who's that? here I am.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.p: Let me embrace you first within my Arms: then call you Lord. The King will have it so: who does intreat your Lordship, to remember his Message, sent to you by Longoville.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: If you are sneaking, and dare mount no higher, you may yield now. I know what I wou'd do.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Peace, he observes us. A Lord, Hum, to be Lord Cockle-brain! Pox, I know a Crook-back'd Fidler call'd a Lord: No, no, this is too light too. Besides I have been sick of a Lord, ever since I met my Lord Mayor t'other Day, ty'd to his Horse, and with a great Brass Chain about his Neck, weighing of Butter.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.p: You'll return the King some Answer, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, you may thank his Majesty, but the Lordship is too light. I must be gone, were he Ten Thousand Kings and Emperours.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.p: I'll tell him what you say, Sir, but I know he'll be extreamly concern'd.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Oh damnably! the Rogue does it to a Hair. Away, away.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.p: I must, or I shall laugh in's Face. Ex. Bew.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Why, this was like your self, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I think so; The Devil's in't, if that was not stiff enough. But if I should lose this Lordship by Fooling, my Wife would be plaguy angry. A Ladyship, you know is a pretty Bawble, enough for her to play with.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Oh, you'll have a bigger Bawble, I warrant you for her to play with. See, see, here comes t'other again.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Give me your honour'd Hand, right Courteous Peer, and from hence forth be a Noble Marquess, the King so wills, and Subjects must obey. Only he still desires you to consider his late Request.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Faith! You are well now, my Lord. I'd consent.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: ' sBud— I'll be one Step higher, since I am so far.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, 'Tis the finest Lord: I am afraid anon, he'll stand upon't to share the Kingdom with him.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Pox on you. Speak lower.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Troth, I must own the King is very gracious: but that scandalous Ballad of that abominable Marquess, and that damnable Patient Grizel, has made that Title so nauseous to me— If his Majesty would but please to change that.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Faith, my Lord, I believe you may be what you please. Here's another Messenger.

div.stage: Enter Bewford, and Footman carrying a Robe.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Make Room here. Where's this Noble Marquess? The King, my Lord, once more has sent me to you, and finding no Dignity above your Merit, so you will freely grant to his Proposal, he bids you be a Duke, and chuse of whence.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: ' sHeart, if you yield not now, you are undone: What can you wish to have more than the Kingdom?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why then, so please his Majesty, I would be Duke of Dunstable; Because I like the Sound.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: 'Tis very apt, Sir: I know the King is pleased. There's your Patent with a Blank.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Pray give his Majesty Thanks, Sir; and you may tell him now that I will stay.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: He'll be a glad man when he hears it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I must have vent to laugh, or I shall burst. Aside.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Keep your Countenance, and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: But how shall we keep it from the Worlds Ear, that none undeceive him?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: We'll think of that anon: Why, Gentlemen, is this a gracious Habit for a Duke? For Heaven's sake each one employ his Hand to pluck the Clouds off from this Radiant Sun, that must shine on us all— I'll pluck one Boot and Spur off.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And I another.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: This scurvey Hat, and plaguy Peruke, do not become his Grace's sprouting Fore-head: For Shame let's off with 'em.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Now set your Duke-like Foot to this of mine, one pluck will do it.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Hold! Hold! thou'lt pluck my Leg off; prithee go more gingerly to work, my Grace is yet but tender.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: My Lord, I beg your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Well— you have it, Friend.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: So, now off with this Jerkin, and throw away that Riding-Rod.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Here, here: on with the new Robe the King has sent.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Robe— 'Tis but an odd sort of a Robe, methinks: Prithee, what's the Name on't?

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: My Lord, 'Tis call'd a Solyman: 'Tis made in Imitation of the new Sultana's; this Mode is for the great Lords, as t'other for the great Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Oh ho! Is it so? They put it on.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: So, So, Where are his Grace's Slippers?

div.stage: Enter Toby, booted and dress'd for a Iourney.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir, all's ready: The Horses are brought out; The Pillion on, and my Mistress stays in the Hall. Ownz! what's here to do? What a Devil do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: My Slippers, Toby, my Slippers. Gravely.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Slippers! 'sbud, will you ride a Journey in your Slippers?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Oh thou mighty Duke! Pardon this Man, that thus has trespass'd in his Ignorance. Here are your Grace's Slippers.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: The poor Fellow is honest— I pardon him.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Fellow, he's a Duke. The King has rais'd him above all the Land. Toby starts, and then kneels.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Duke! Oh, that ever I was born! Do you hear, Sir, Do you know what I am, pray?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Chief Gentleman o'th' Chamber; Secretary, any thing, what you please: you may be a Lord in time, if things go right. To Long.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: D'ye hear, Friend? Prithee pull off my Boots too.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: No, let them alone, and get thee into the Countrey presently, and tell my Uncle what has happen'd.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: 'sHeart, here's Luck for you. I'll post thither instantly, and tell his Uncle this amazing News. Oh what dull Dunghill Countrey Rogues are we! A Duke! 'sheart, we shall be all Lords at least. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Aurelia, dress'd awkwardly for a Iourney.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Thus to your Will, as every good Wife ought, I have bent all my Thoughts, and now am ready.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Oh Madam! I am not worthy to kiss the least of all your Grace's Toes, much less your Thumb, which yet I would be bold with. All your Council has been to me as prudent as an Angel's, but mine to thee as dirty as my Boots. Dear Dutchess, there's no going now, we must both stay.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, don't mock me, nor make me dress and undress like a Fool, because you find me easy: said I not, the whole World should not alter me, if once I were resolv'd; therefore let's away.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Behold, a Knight does kneel. Kneels.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: A Knight!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: A Lord.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: A Fool!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I say a Lord does kneel, nay a Duke.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: In Trowses, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Without Shoes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Are you all mad?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No, gracious Lady, if you dare credit your faithful Servant's Word, Your Husband's made a Duke.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What think you now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Ah dear, dear Dutchess! I am made by thee for ever, and here in Token, that all Strife shall end, 'twixt Thee and Me, I let my Trowses fall, and to thy Hands I do deliver 'em,
sp.l: To signifie, that in all Acts and Speeches,
From this time forth my Wife shall wear the Breeches.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: WELL avads! You are welcome home a thousand times, dear Hubby; and will my Cousin be here so soon do you say?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Ay, I have laid it home to him, i'faith! I have made a new Man of him! we shall have no more Court Fooleries now!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why, Hubby, is not the Court a fine Place then?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Not half so fine a Place as my Barn is in Harvest-time.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What, and so many tall, young, handsome, Scotch, French and Irish Wits there, that come for Preferment? Why, Hubby, I heard here that my Cousin Cockle-brain was to have been made a Lord.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: A Lord! A Loggerhead he would have been made, had not I clear'd his Eye-sight, what with his Wife's Tattling, and her Bullies Bantring him with Honours and Titles, he was almost mad amongst 'em: but I rouz'd him, i'faith! I got the better of him at last, and made him forswear ever coming near that damn'd Town again. I expect him here to morrow; He's upon his Journey by this time.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What has he forsworn sweet London, to come and live sneaking here in the Country, Hubby?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Sweet London! 'sbud I warrant this Fool thinks it pav'd with Nutmegs and Ginger; ha, ha:— besides, why sneaking, you Baggage? why sneaking?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why is not our Countrey Life a sneaking Life, Hubby?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: No, Hubby, and let me hear you call it so agen, if you dare: I shall have her get an Itch of seeing this sweet London, and run away from me there, if I han't a Care. Aside.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay, Dear, pray don't be angry! what Preferment can my Cousin expect here?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: ' sBud, is he not Lord of a Mannor? which he may thank me for too, for that was just degrading, had not I been in the way, and exercis'd upon him: besides, if he wants more Preferment, he may be a Iustice of Peace, as I am: Lash the Whores out of the Countrey; live godlily, and take Bribes, ye silly Jade.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He's coming, Hubby, for look here comes his Man, Mr. Toby.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: 'Tis he, i'faith! What, Toby— my Friend, Toby! welcome, faith: Spouse, go lay down the Pheasant Roger shot this Morning: I suppose my Cousin's alighted at the Gate, and we must get something to entertain him; go, go; why don't you move? now I see, Toby, he's a Man of his Word. Ownds run, lay down the Pheasant, I say. Pushes her.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Your Pheasant must fly into St. Iames's Park if you intend to treat him, I can tell you that.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Why, is not he come?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: No, nor like to come, that's more, Old Fellow.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: How, Sauce box! What's that you say? Will he break his Word with me? does the Rascal dare to affront me?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Rascal! Have a Care what you say, Friend, I have sworn Homage to my Prince, and hold my Place by my Fidelity, therefore, Friend, keep good Words in your Mouth. You are but a Iustice of Peace.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: But a Iustice of Peace! Why, you sawcy Rascal, what would you have me be, a Cherubin? Here's an insolent Rogue! He makes nothing of a Iustice of Peace.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Not in Comparison of his Grace, or my self, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: His Grace! whose Grace, Dog? 'sbud, speak quickly, and don't plague me with these Riddles, or old Crab shall fly about your Ears? Why does that Scab, your Master, use me thus? and where is he?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: His Mighty Grace is at his House, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Mighty Grace!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Hubby, prithee do not call my Court-Nephew such Names!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Old Mole hill! things are alter'd since thou and I met at London: to be short, the King has made your Nephew Duke of Dunstable: now repent of what is past, and extend your Manners to me, as my Place deserves, or look to't. I shall stick upon your Skirts: I shall grub ye!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: The Duke of Dunstable, Oons!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Even so, Sir, and greatest Favourite at Court, no better, nor no worse, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: But, Toby, dost not thou dream? Art sure?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Sir, I'll hold no Discourse without my Title. If you want Court Breeding I'll teach you some. I am stil'd now Mr. Secretary.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Mr. Secretary!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A little Step to future Dignity. About two Years hence I expect to be a Duke my self.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: The Devil you do! This must be down-right Madness.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Believe so, and be wretched!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I beseech you, good Mr. Secretary, be not angry! 'Tis such high News it almost gravels me: I desire only to be satisfy'd, and if you are sure my Nephew is a Duke.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: As sure as you are Justice Grub, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: And that's pretty sure indeed. Gadzooks, if this be true I have undone my self, I call'd him Son of a Whore! But, Mr. Secretary, I have great Confidence in your Worship's Patience and Mercy. Changing his Tone.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Iustice, I can wink at Faults.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: But if the Sun should dazle now!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yet more Doubts! Have you a Nose on your Face?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: A Nose! Yes, yes; I am sure I have a Nose.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why then I am sure he is a Duke.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O Gemini! If our Nephew be a Duke, I wonder what I am, Hubby!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: A Fool, Hubby. Pox, prithee hold thy peace; I'll tell thee more anon: this is the rarest News! We are all made for ever.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I saw the Courtiers bow, and heard 'em cry, Good Health and Fortune to my Lord the Duke; God bless him, cries another; and to his Grace's right Hand, the Worshipful Mr. Secretary, says a third: And when I came away to bring this News, his Chamber was hung with Nobles like the Presence.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I heartily thank you, Sir, I am satisfy'd. Why, Great as he is, he is my Kinsman, Mr. Secretary; I am his poor unworthy Uncle.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: That's true, Sir; but I could wish his Greatness could make him lose his Memory; you have been formerly a little sawcy with him, you know, Justice.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I have so indeed, a great Failing in troth: I am asham'd on't heartily; and will repent and mend. What, I warrant his ingenious Lady was the Means of all this!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Even so, Sir; You know I was for having you swinge her, Gadzooks, I would not have her know it for a 1000 l.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Nor I have done it for Ten thousand.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: For she has ferk'd out all our Preferments upon her own Anvil, as cleverly as a Smith would do a Ten penny Nail.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Ah, I always thought her an ingenious Person. But now to see what Fortune some Men have! I might have been a Duke too, if I had had but Luck. I had an Estate and a Wife as fair as his, that could have brook'd the Court as well as his, and laid about her for her Husband's Honour. Ah, Toby, had I ever dreamt of this!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yet again, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I cry your Mercy, good Mr. Secretary.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why faith, Sir, it came above our Expectation: we were wise only in seeking to undo this Honour: which shew'd our Dung-hill Breeding, and our Dirt.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, we were both arrant Puppies, Mr. Secretary. 'Tis as his Noble Grace hath often said, we understood just nothing.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p:
'Tis Time then that we now improve our selves, that rising,
as we may, with our great Master, we may attain some Wisdom with our Places, and not be Fools in Office, Mr. Justice.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Right; and Troth this Grandeur of the Duke's, my Nephew, I cry thy Mercy that I am familiar, methinks should make for us. Hum!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: How the Fates may order in this poor Thread of Life, as yet I know not; but I think I was not born to hold a Trencher: Let Time rowl on, I shall see what 'twill come to!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Well, The first thing I'll do, I'll fit my Wife for the Court; Buy her new Cloaths, and Trinckets.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: That's the Way, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I was a dull Countrey Clod, to let my Nephew rise and get the start before me. But I'll dispatch and put my self in Money.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: To buy me fine Cloaths, Hubby! O Gemini! And must I go to Court then; And see the fine Houses, and the fine Horses, and the fine Gentlemen that I have dreamt of a thousand times, when you have been talking the Night before, ivads I have, Hubby.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Thou shalt see all: It shall go hard but I'll have Preferment too. I'll about this Money instantly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh Gemini! I could leap out of my Skin for Joy methinks!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: You do well, Sir, and now you talk of Money, the former Business, for taking up the five hundred Pounds, must be dispatch'd; This little Plat in the Countrey lies most fit to do his Grace such serviceable Uses.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: By no means, Mr. Secretary; his Grace shall have it of me, 'twill be a Courtly Complement, to introduce my self.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why, Troth, I thought so, but would not be too forward.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Oh, by all means, Sin, come, come! pray walk in, Wife, conduct Mr. Secretary into the Buttery; and desire him to take a Glass of what we have: And d'ye hear, recommend your self handsomely to the great Duke, our Kinsman, and his Dutchess; and write them word you shall attend 'em suddenly. I'll go and dispatch these Bills, and follow you. Zooks! I hardly know where I am.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Sir, I shall wait on you.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: By no means, Sir, 'tis much below your Place.

sp.speaker: Phil.
