sp.p: Come, sweet Mr. Secrecy, please to walk in, I know not what to get that's good enough for you, for ivads you have made me a joyful Creature!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Keep your Joy till you come to Court, pretty Mistress!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: And that shall be quickly, i'faith, since there are Dukedoms, and Don-ships, and the Devil and all to be gotten so easily: I'll trouble my self no more with Sowing and Reaping; but laugh and lye at Ease, let the Weather change as it will: I know I shall be a Devil of a Courtier the first Year; But what then, my Wife shall shine for us both.
sp.l: And toy and treat, whilst I wink at the Matter,
But for the rest, odzooks, I'll watch her Water. Exit.

div.head: SCENE I. Cockle-brain's House.
div.stage: Enter Aurelia, Longoville, Bewford and Clermont.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: It must be carried closely with a Care, that no Man speak to him, or come near him without our private Knowledge, and then my good dull, honest, drowsie Husband you shall not hinder me from the Pleasure of Basset: And I will go into the Countrey when I please, and not when you think fit.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Let him be kept in's Chamber under Show of State, and Dignity, and no one suffer'd to see his Noble Face, or have Access, but we that are Conspirators.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Or else down with him into the Countrey, amongst his Tenants, where he may live much safer in his Greatness, and play the Fool in Pomp amongst his Fellows.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No, he shall play the Fool in the City first: I will not lose the Honour of the Jest, that shall be given my Wit, for all his Land i'th' Country.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Alas, poor Duke! I do but think how he will sweat when he finds at last he is made an Ass on.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: In the mean time we'll keep a Guard about his Person, that no Man come too near him, and our selves always in Company have him into the City to see his Face swell, whilst in divers Corners some of our own appointing shall be ready to cry, Heaven bless your Grace, Long live your Grace.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Twill be rare Sport, and shall be as rarely follow'd: I'll teach him to rail at me for losing Sonicà. To think Beauty, such as mine, was only fit to wither in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Bewf
sp.p: Poor sordid Earth-worm!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I can scarce hold from open Laughter, when I hear him cry, come hither, my sweet Dutchess; let me kiss thy gracious Lips: for this is still his Phrase. I shall fear nothing but his Legs will break under the mighty Weight of so much Greatness.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Hark, hark! He's coming: set your Faces right, and bow like Countrey Prologues. Here he comes. Room, Room, before there: The Duke is entring.

div.p: The choicest Blessings wait upon the Duke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And give him all Content and Happiness.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Let his great Name live to the end of Time.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I thank you all; and am pleas'd to give you Notice, at a fit Time, I shall consider of you: till when be near me: My dear Dutchess, prithee let thy Grace lend me thy Keys; there is a Book of Heraldry in thy Closet, I must peruse.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Here they are, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: He does it to a Hair.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Is he not a Duke indeed? He's alter'd so, he's now scarce knowable.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Get Candles there.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Lights, Lights there for the Duke. Ex. Cockl.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: His very Stile and Air alter'd: Why, here's the Effect of Grandeur, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: The Duke! What Duke is this, ha? Do you know him?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Tis the poor mad Gentleman I told you of; he runs thus over all the Town, and where he finds a Door open, he enters.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Or is the lucky Favourite made a Duke, He that has married Celia?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: What Celia, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: I know not what I say, Sir: you shall not snap me: this is no Treason: I said only Celia, she was my Love, Sir, in Diebus illis, But now alas!

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Where is she, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Dead! Dead! SINGS.
In yonder Cowslip lies my Dear,
Intomb'd with liquid Gems of Dew;
Each day I'll water't with a Tear,
Its fading Blossom to renew. Alas, poor Soul! she dy'd of the Heart-burning, in spight of the Benefit of Crabs Eyes or Spaw-water, Sir: you are an Apothecary.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Alas, poor Wretch!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: You have a strange odd kind of an Apocryphal Phiz; methinks a Face that's full of hard Words: Zowns, Sir, d'ye come to pose me? I am a Scholar.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: He knows it, Sir, and knows Celia too, who greets you kindly, and would not have you be so melancholly.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Thank her; but 'tis too late, tell her! SINGS.
I'll lay me down and dy within some hollow Tree,
The Raven and Cat, the Owl and Bat shall warble out my Elegy.
How d'ye like that Dirge now, was it not quaint?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I have found the Book of Heraldry.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: A Book of Heraldry! Have you so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: How now! Who's this? Yes, Sir, that I have: what then?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Here's like to be rare Sport!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: We can't miss it, now the Fool and Madman are met.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: What then? Why then, Sir, I suppose you were sent to dispute with me about King Henry's Title: Come on, Sir: I'll be cunning enough, I warrant you, Begin, state your Point.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: A strange sort of Fellow this! does any here know him?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I believe your Grace will find him a Male-content, sent by some Enemies that envy your new Greatness, to pump your Loyalty with a fallacious Argument about the King's Title.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Oh, is that the Business? Well; I'll be prepar'd for him, I'll warrant ye: Come, Sir, sit down; I'll clear this Business: Henry of Hereford, Son of Iohn of Gaunt.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Sir, I shall answer nothing, till these Witnesses depart the Room; you must not think to trap me.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Pray leave us together: I'll have no Man stay; no not my Dutchess.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Come, let's go, and behind the Hangings hear this fine Argument. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Henry of Hereford, Son of Iohn a Gaunt, Impeach'd of Treason by Thomas Duke of Norfolk, demanded Combat.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and what then?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Pray give me leave, Sir: But King Richard the second loving and fearing his great Uncle Lancaster, deferr'd the Fight, and banish'd both the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Sir, give me better Reasons for his Banishment, or yield your self confuted.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: What, before we have half done. Pray give me leave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, give me leave: I'll give you better Reasons, They swell within me, and must have vent.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Will you but hear me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: I'll hear nothing, Sir, till I have fill'd your Belly full of Reasons: I say, King Richard, Sir, forbid the Combat, doubting the Justice of his Kinsman's Cause; and therefore, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I know what you infer, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Sir, you know nothing: for then comes Vortigern the Saxon Monarch, and cuts off the Entail.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Ownds, what Entail? The Devil's in this Fellow; He's running back to the beginning of the World, if I don't contradict him: why what has Vortigern to do with Richard the second?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: How, Sir, not to do with him? Did they not combat on the Bank of Humber, and thump each other soundly for the Kingdom, with Batts and Sand-bags?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: No, Sir, that ever I could read.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Why then you are a Traytor, and I arrest you of High Treason, for not knowing History better, and seize you on the behalf of Vortigern.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Pox on Vortigern and you too. Seize me? alas, poor Fellow! know'st thou who I am?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: I care not what you are: Come along to Prison, and willingly, or I'll plume thee as a Hawk does a Partridge.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: The Devil is certainly in this Fellow: within there? who waits?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Do you rebel? Thus I claim the Combate. beats Cock.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Help, Help, here. Enter Footmen.

div.stage: Enter Aurelia, Clermont, Longoville, and Bewford.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: How now? Alas, what's the matter here?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Help, help thy Duke here!

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Take him off; forbear his Grace's Person.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: A Horse; a Horse; my Kingdom for a Horse: What's here, a Woman, charging at their Army's Head? then we are betray'd.

q.l: I'll mount to you, blue Coelum,
To shun these Female Gypsies;
I'll play at Bowles with Sun and Moon,
And scare ye with Eclipses.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Away, away with him.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: How, seiz'd! then here's my Ransom: This was my Father's Sword, I'll call it Vortigern: It lightens when I draw it, and when I strike it thunders!

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Away with him, the Man's mad. How does your Grace?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Indifferent well; but I believe he has broke my Head with the Hilt of Vortigern.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: How did you find his Title, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: The Devil take his Title and him too. Dear Dutchess, prithee go get me a Plaister.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: It needs not, my Lord; 'tis nothing but a Contusion, upon my Honour, and nothing so good for it as Air. Will your Grace be pleas'd to see the City?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: It shall be so: prepare there. A Plague o'this Vortigern! Aside.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Your Grace determines not to see the King.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Not yet: about some ten Days hence I shall be ready.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Clear the way there: Room for the Duke! Ex. Cockl.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Away, before, Bewford, and raise a Guard sufficient to keep him from the reach of Peoples Tongues, and remember how the Streets must be dispos'd with Cries and Salutations: in the mean time, Madam, you keep your State at home. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; thus far 'tis acted rarely: what hereafter I do intend, lies not within your level, my sweet Friends; nor shall not, till 'tis ripe for a Discovery. Enter Page with a Letter.

div.p: As I live, from my new Countrey Aunt, I know the Hand: To the great Lady, High and Mighty Dutchess of Dunstable, be these delivered: Ha, ha, ha, Oh for a stronger Lace to keep my Breath in, that I my laugh the nine Days, till the Wonder fall to an Ebb! What high and mighty Blockheads live in the Countrey!
My good angry Uncle, I find, by the Contents, you want Preferment too, and you shall have it, or my Wit shall fail me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Madam, I hope you'll pardon this Intrusion: 'twas told me that a poor distracted Gentleman, that owes his great Misfortue
to my Folly, was seen to enter here; Pray is it so?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Such a one, Madam, has been here, indeed, but he is gone: Was he your Husband, Madam?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: That he was not my Husband, was the Cause that he is nothing now: curst lawless Force, and impious Cruelty, ravish'd the Blessing from his longing Heart, and cast a Mist before my feeble Eyes, blinded by Wealth and treacherous Dignity, I could not see his Merit, till too late.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I hope he's not past Cure, Madam?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: There's a Physician learn'd in these Extreams, that gives me mighty hopes, if he were taken!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I believe, Madam, my Servants can give you some Account of him: if you please I'll examine them.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: The Courtesie will be both generous and charitable.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Madam, You should command far greater Services than these, if they were in my Power. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III. The Street.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Every Man take his Corner, here am I, you, and you in that place, and as he comes by, be sure you salute him with loud Voices, and Faces full of dejected Fear and Humbleness. Away, he's coming.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Fy! How these streets are throng'd here with these same rascally People. I am just come to Town, and, as I am a Gentleman, am almost choak'd already, with the very Steam of 'em: They have crowded his Grace almost to Death yonder, they follow him like a Baboon to the Bear-Garden. There is in the World no true Gaper like your Citizen: the Bears shall not pass by his Door in Peace, but that he, and all his Family shall be ready to ride upon the Backs of 'em. Room, before there.

div.stage: Enter Cockle-brain, Clermont, Longoville, and Servants.
div.p: A Pox on you, keep your Places, and then you may see him till your Hearts ake.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Bless your Grace.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: And you, with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Heaven grant your Grace long Life, and happy Days.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Thank thee, good Friend.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Perpetual Blessings crown you.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I thank you all. Longoville.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I'll make a Speech to 'em. Hem, hem!

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Silence there, his Grace will make a Speech.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Good People! I shall divide my Speech into three Branches; First, it has pleas'd the King, my Master, for sundry Virtues in me, not unknown to Him, and the wise State, to lend his Hand, and raise me to this Eminence: My second Branch is to examine how this may seem to other Men, or stir the Minds of such as are my Fellow-Peers against me; since I desire, and will deserve their Loves, as I do yours, good People. My third and last Branch is upon Amity, for as the Tree—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Your Grace had best take care, 'twill be inform'd the King, your Greatness with the People.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: A Pox on him! he has hindred me from branching into the finest Metaphor, and I am the worst in the World to get in again when I am once out: My last Branch, I say, dear Friends, is, Hem, hem! a Plague of this Clermont! is, I say,— Faith, I know not what it is at present— But if ever you catch me branching it again, in this Fellow's Company— I'll give you leave to hang me upon the Tree I was speaking of, And so I share my Bowels amongst you all.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: A Noble Duke! a very Noble Duke! Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV. Cockle-brain' s Hall.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Is my Uncle coming, art sure?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
As sure as he expects to be made a Duke too, Madam.
Lord, methinks, I long to see his new Countrey Wife, I wonder how the Creature looks.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Very prettily, as I have heard: 'Twill be Diversion to see how our Court Sparks will ogle her Countrey Dress.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and paddle in the Palm of her Hand.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, your Gypsie, and go and see what time the Coach comes in: I must set another Springe ready to catch the Buzzard, my Uncle; I'll teach him to preach against the Court and my Town Pleasures. Hark! His Grace, the Duke is coming. Away, away to your Business.

div.p: Your Grace is welcome home.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why, thank your Grace. How fine these Titles sound, Sweet-Heart, I am well and merry, never more able to be thy Bedfellow, my Dearest.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Bless us, what a hot Meat this Greatness is!

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: It may well be, for he has not got a snap these two Months, to my Knowledge, or is she damn'd for swearing it.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: I thank you, Gentlemen, for your Attendance, and your great Pains, pray know my Lodgings better and oftner: do so Gentlemen: now by my Honour, as I am a Prince, I will consider your Deservings. Toby.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.p: Where's Mr Secretary, there? Some body call him.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Mr. Secretary!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: His Grace wants you, Mr. Secretary.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Toby.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Be ready for the Countrey once more, Toby: And let my Tenants know the King's great Love; say I would see 'em; But the weight of State lies heavy on my Shoulders, and therefore tell 'em, I expect their Attendance. Go, take up Post-Horses, and make haste.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I begin to find this under-hand Dignity a little troublesome, and care not much for jumbling my Honour thus a Horseback. Well, for this once I'll be a Servant; but when I come back, I'll try if I can set up for a Duke, as well as others.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: My gracious Husband, you must now prepare in all your Pomp, to entertain your Uncle, who is a Convert now. And with his Wife intends to be here to night.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p:
Alas, poor Countrey things, how they will blush to see my Grandeur! But I will be pitiful, Gentlemen, pray be ready, I do intend to morrow early,
To shew before my Uncle's wondring Face,
The Greatness of my Pomp, and of my Place.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: We'll all be ready. Away, Boys, till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: This Countrey Uncle must needs prove a rare new Scene of Diversion.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Most certainly, in the mean, let's to Pontack's to Supper. Exeunt Omnes.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: ARE all things carry'd to the Taylor! Roger?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: All, All, an't shall please you: che were with 'en by break of Day, along while avore yow were out of your Neast, an't shall please you.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: That's well; we must know of the Duke my Cosin, Wife, what Fashion his Grace will please to have us in? For my own part, I have an old fashion'd Velvet pair of Breeches, that when I have made a new Suit and Cloak of 'em, will steal into the Presence well enough.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And does your Worship intend to leave Plowden Hicket, and your House in the Country for good and all, an't shall please you?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: As his Mighty Grace, my Nephew thinks fit: 'Tis as preferment comes, Roger!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Gads bread; and thick vine Gown will make Mistress look like a Countess too, an't shall please you.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Ay, ay, before the Duke and the Court have done with her, I hope to see her look like a Dutchess, Roger. Come, Wife; What are you staring at?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh Iemmini! Hubby— I never saw so curious a place in my life: The Trumpets and the Drums make so pure a noise, methinks I am almost substracted with it: And look, look, Hubby what are these Birds that fly over our Heads?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Ducks, Ducks, Fool.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Good me! and why do they fly about so? And, pray Hubby, tell me who's that naked Black Man, that holds a thing in his hand so.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p:
O Lord! a naked Black Man with a thing in his hand, was there ever such a Fool? why, that is a Statue! a Gladiator, a thing set up for Ornament; or to scare the Rooks here about
the Court— A Pox I can't tell what it's for? Come prithee, Come along.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Nay, pray Hubby; let me know all the fine things. And what are those that lye there by the Water side, Hubby.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Geese, Geese, you Fool! odszooks! those! no, those are Gentlemen of the Guard that lye a Sunning: s'bud She'll tire me with questions! if I stay longer— Come, come prithee, come away— Roger! a word.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Lol-throl-lol— How now! what pretty Country thing is this, that stares at me? I'le speak to her: Your Servant, pretty Mistress, whither are you a going?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh Gemini! what a pure sweet fine young Gentleman is here? Indeed Sir, I don't know! but I think I am going home with my Hubby!

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Her Hubby— what a pox is that, her Hobby-horse?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: You're mistaken here, Friend, She's meat for your Master— hum hum— Grub. pulls her away.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Why then, Friend, I would my Master had her; and so your Servant— Exit.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh law! Do you know him then! prithee dear Hubby, who is it?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Odzooks! a lowzy Footman, that I would not have had his Grace seen you talk with for 1000 l.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: What, a Footman, with thick vine Silver lac'd Coat on's back, as sure as cham here, I should have taken him to be a Knight of the Shire at least, if chad seen him come riding through Plowden.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Oh thou art come to a new World, Roger, the Lords and the Lacquies are all brave alike here!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Would I were at home agen for my part, and sitting by the fire with old Ioan— I'de ne're come here to seek for parferment, not I; odsooks! the Cries of the Street, and the ratling of the Coaches have almost maz'd me: besides, chant slep a wink since che come to Town.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p:
Hold your Tongue, ye Clodpole: Don't you see what
preferment your Country-man Toby is come to? And if I can get to be a Duke, as if my Wife manages well, I intend to be, who knows, but thou mayst come to be Secretary as well as he Buffle?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Should not a Secretary Write and Read, an't shall please you?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: 'Tis all one; some do, and some do not, if he has but a Clark that can, 'tis no matter whether he can Write and Read, or no? But come, by this time his Grace is rising: lets go and give our attendance. Nay, prithee come away; What-a-devil art thou staring at?— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Save you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Save the King▪ Sir

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Pray Sir, which is the nearest way?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Save the King, I say, Sir, this is the nearest way.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: The nearest way, I mean to the Post house, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Gad save the King and his Post horse, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, direct me to the House

sp.speaker: Lyon
sp.p: Here must be no directions; you cannot catch me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I don't understand you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Read Hugo Grotius then. I say you can't catch me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Not catch you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: No Sir, nor can the King with all his cunning Stratagems and Plots, although he put his Nobles in disguise, never so oft, to sift into my words by course of Law lay hold upon my Life.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: This must be some business that the Duke my Master is by the King employ'd in, and he thinks that I, as being Secretary, am acquainted with it— hum hum.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: I shall not need to rip the Cause up to you, nor need you tell me the place you hold i'th State— I know your Name is Phizgigg.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Phisgigg, Sir!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Ay— by the Mothers side you come from the Right Honourable the Bominellies; you give for your Coat Argent, a Polcat Mountant Azure, a Bar direct between Culters pendant Sables: You are, Sir, sprung of a great Family.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: An ingenuous Fellow, this, I warrant him: s'bud, he knows more of me than I ever knew of myself.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Besides, you have a scar upon the top of your Nose, which denotes Dignity, a Semicircle upon your Crown, and a double fold upon your right Ear: your Great Unkle was a Bassaw.

div.stage: Tweaks him by the Nose, and Cuffs him.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Bassaw, s'heart, this fellow will make a Great Turk of me presently— I have lately come to some preferment indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing, you shall have more, and greater: Let me see— You shall be before Christmas next—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Duke, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: A Duke at least.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Odsheart! I thought so always! I know I was not born to hold a Trencher: this is a most admirable Man!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: But there is one ill Planet that hangs o're you.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: An ill one! a lack-a-day— What is it. Sir?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Saturn! Saturn! you will within this hour be taken up for High Treason!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Bless me! for High Treason!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Has no one seen you talk with me, think you?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes, a great many, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: There 'tis, there's your undoing: I am pursu'd by the whole State! Continual Treasons laid to my Charge, and all that talk with me fall into the same predicament. I cannot help weeping, to think you should fall, into such danger for my sake!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: S'heart! would you had been hanged e're I had fallen into the predicament, as you call it. weeps.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: You will be apprehended within this half hour, you are beset already—' oh— weeps.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I'le whip out of Town.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Oh— then your Head's whipt off the next minute, if you but offer at that. Oh—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why the Devil did you stop me, could you not be contented to be hang'd by your self like a good Christian. But on my Conscience, this comes of my Ambition, my plotting to be a Duke before my time.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh! Both howl out.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: But, good Sir, is there no remedy?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Yes, yes— Fate does allow a remedy; but then you must take a Manly resolution, and suffer your self to be hang'd little, to appease the Fates.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh a little! pray how little will serve, Sir! for you know there's no jesting with those things.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Why, two or three hours hanging will do it, I am sure; and if you can endure that bravely, you will certainly live to be a Great Man.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh Lord; 'Tis impossible: I know my Constitution so well, Sir, that I shall be choak'd in half the time: But if punishment for a High Misdemeanor, instead of High Treason would serve turn, I would be burnt in the Hand with all my heart; if that would appease the Fates.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: 'Twas generously said; and 'tis pity such Honor e're should be a prey to Fortune: Take Courage, Friend, I will preserve thy life with hazard of my own.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Blessing on your Heart.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: This night thou shalt be lock'd within my Doors, and in the Morning I'le so provide, that in disguise you shall have free access to the Sea-side, and then, e're any know it, be Shipp'd away for Bantam.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: For Bantam! Gadsooks! that's a devilish way: What shall I do when I am there? Oh Fortune, Fortune! but come, any thing's better than hanging by the Neck two or three hours, in hopes to be a Great Man after it.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Follow me softly then, and no more Thoughts of Honor, d'ye hear: lest the Fates frown, and contradict our purposes.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ah no, no, Sir, my Pride is fallen low enough by this time. This comes of my Ambition, Rogue, Pimp, Scoundril as I was— I must be a Duke in the Devils name— Oh, I deserve to be hang'd, that's the Truth on't—
Lyonel, Toby go above.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: This is his House, and here I saw him enter; his better Angel has directed him to leave the wandring streets— poor, Gentleman, would I were able, with as free a Heart, to set his Soul right, as I am to grieve the ruine of his Sense, which Heaven forgive me!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: If you could win him but to take my Medicine, and get some Rest, my Life upon the Operation.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I'le call to him: Sir, if you are within, pray speak to me.

div.p: Yes Sir, I am within, and will be.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh, oh— Who is't, Good Sir, Who is't?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: The Captain of the Guards: take heed you are not seen: there the Disguise lies; on with it immediately, 'twas what I had provided for myself— but you shall be serv'd first now, Friend.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sir— here's a friend of yours would speak with you

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: A Friend! no Sir, you must pardon me— I am acquainted with no such— I see you are a Switzer by your Habit.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Alas! poor Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Switzer! Oh Lord, what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Sir, I am a Messenger from her you love: nay, and from her that loves you more than Life, more than fresh springing Flowers the indulgent Sun; or pretty Birds enfriar'd their liberty: and can you be so cruel not to hear me?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Let it suffice that you hear me, and hear me loudly, once more, God Save the King. Come Friend, are you ready— the Troops are all drawn off, the Coast is clear now, only the Captain and the Switzer.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And what's to be done with 'em, Good Sir?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: We'l scow'r 'em, Boy, we'l scow'r 'em: you shall bring up the rear. I'le Charge i'th' Van! nay, prithee, why dost thou shake so?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Alas! Sir— 'Tis impossible for me to Charge, I am turn'd Woman now! Toby comes down.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Why then I'le do't myself: This bloody Sword through millions of our Foes shall be thy Guard, and let thee safe aboard.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Come, Madam, let us be gone: This is no time to stay to tempt his Fury: we'l take a fitter season.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Heaven send it.—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: They are gone sure! I can see no body. Oh how I shake! would I were safe under hatches once, that I might be out of my fears— Farewel— the Court now; Instead of being a Duke, or at least a Baron, I am going the Devil knows where, to Bantam? And farewel, my dear Lord too— I shall never see thy Glorious Face agen— Oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: How now! Who's here, another Undertaker? Another Plot upon me?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Sir, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: I. Why who are you?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Your Friend, Sir— whom you are sending to Bantam?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Bantam; and my Friend: here's a sly trick now, they know I have no Woman Friend but one, who is too closely kept from me, to be here: pray, come hither and let me look on you.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why Sir, 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: You should not be a Woman by your stature!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I am none, Sir— I am none.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: I know it then, keep off:
Strange Men and Times! How am I still preserv'd?
Here they have sent a Yeoman of the Guard,
Disguis'd in Womans Cloaths, to work upon me,
To make Love to me, to trap my Words,
And to ensnare my Life, keep off, I say.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh do not leave me, I beseech you, Sir, for I shall ne'r be able to find the way to Bantam, without you.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Ha— are not these my Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, you lent 'em me to make escape in.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Here's an impudent Rogue: First rob me, and then talks of making his escape— Come, strip, sirra— I'le make an example of you.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh Lord, strip, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Ay, ay, all off Rogue, and presently, or I will pound thee into Mortar. Strips Toby.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh dear Toby. What will become of thee?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: The Drawers too, Rogue; the Drawers.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: The Drawers— Why Sir, I shall be naked, for I've but a half Shirt on.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Sirra— If you have but a half Breech on, I'le see what you have!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh the Devil's in this Fellow. I must run for't, he'l flea me else. Starts from him, and runs out.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Hah, fled— Why then, like conquering Tamberlain, I carry off the spoils— Victoria, Victoria.

div.stage: Enter Grub. Phillida, and Roger, in tawdry new Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Wife— be sure you hold up your Head now; and primm it as you did one Sanday at Church in the Country, when you put the Parson out of his Sermon, with staring at you— and let the Courtiers see you understand your self! do you hear?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I warrant you, Hubby, let me alone for primming out.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: This is a woundy gallant place, an't like your Worship. There's ne're a Chamber che ha gone through, but is as big as our Town-Hall at Plowden, an't shall please you.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Peace! peace, the Door opens, and two Gentlemen are coming this way: Wife, look to your Enter Longovil and Bewford. self. Roger, be mannerly. I'le speak to 'em. Save you, Gentlemen! belong you, I beseech you, to his Mighty Grace the Duke?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: We do, Sir, and are your Servants. S'life! What pretty Country Creature's that?

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: If there be any thing that we can serve you in, to his Grace, Sir, be pleas'd to Command us.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Gentlemen both— I thank you, Roger, your Hat, under your Arm— Sirra! when did you hear such words before. Wife— hush— Answer nothing: let me alone with 'em. Pray Gentlemen; is it sit so mean a person as myself should desire the favour, as that you would be pleas'd to help me to the Speech of the Great Duke your Master—

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Sir, we shall be proud to serve you. Pox on him, what a Tone the Rogue has?

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Be pleas'd, Sir, to discuss your Business, and your Name, And we will presently inform him of ye.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: O Iemini, Roger! I never heard such fine talk in my life; why, our Minister at home is nothing to 'em.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Ah, thick Gentlemen would make a fool of him, quick alack, they are too vine to have much Religion in 'em.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Well, well, Roger, I hope to be too fine myself too shortly.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Leave your chattering, and be hang'd, and don't discover your Country breeding, ye silly Baggage— aside. Gentlemen both— my Name is Grub.

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Grub. I cry you mercy, Sir, you are his Graces Kinsman, if I mistake not.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Troth Gentlemen, I think there may be a quart or two of his Graces. Blood in me— if I may be so bold.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Sir, no doubt, but you have a gallon of it in you, and we must all be yours, his Graces Kinsman. And we so much forgetful, 'twas a rudeness, we must beg pardon for, and beg the favour to welcome you to Town. kess Grub.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Your servant, Sir, they flabber confoundedly, thô.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Oh Lord, what do thick Men mean by Bussing my Master?

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Next Madam, to you we humbly address our selves! A Cherubim, by this Light. aside. They kiss Phillida.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: This kissing is the worst Fashion in the Court; would they would leave it off— Come hither, Wife— whisper.

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: 'Tis He! this is the Unkle; I find it now; dost hear Bewf. He must be preferr'd too?

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: And so he shall, if all the Art we have can make him noble. I'l dubb him with a Cuckoldom— if his Wife will but join issue.

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Soft and fair, Sir, we must draw lots about that business.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Throw away that Pole, and be hang'd! What a devil dost think we are come to play a Hit at Quarter-staff! we stand upon our preferment; therefore take care of your Behaviour, Booby.

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Wilt please you, Sir, to walk a turn or two here in th' Anti-chamber, whilst to his Grace we make your coming known.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir,— I shall attend his pleasure. Now, Roger, what think'st thou: Is not this rare— ha!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: The Gentlevolkes are huge loving, an't like your Worship, Godsdiggers, I was afraid they would have Buss'd me too.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh dear Hubby— lets never go into the Country agen; Foh— methinks. Plowden is such a stinking dunghil to this sweet place!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Odsooks— the door opens now, now hold up your Head, and Primm, be sure.

div.stage: SCENE, Discovers Cockle-brain seated with Aurelia, Maria, Longovile, Clerimont, Bewford, Servants. They place Grub and his Wife in a Chair.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh Iemmini! Is that he, Hubbi?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Ay— Godsooks is it: make a low Curtsy, quickly ye Jade. Most Gracious Duke— my— poor Bowing. Spowse, and my Self, do kiss your mighty Boot, and next to that, the great Hand of your Dutchess; ever wishing you Fame and Honor springing as your years!

sp.speaker: Cockle.
sp.p: Unkle, you are welcome!

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Pithy and short.

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: And stately too, I'le assure you.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Look, look— the old Gib-Cat is got down on's Knees.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p:
Oh! High and mighty Duke. Your Graces Vassal, far
unworthy the nearness of your Blood— Wife! down on your Mari-bones. She kneels.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: I swear, the prettiest Wench— that e're I saw.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Oh! is she so, Sir?— Come, come, here are the Lots!

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Now, Fortune— They Draw.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Mine by Heav'n! and you are to assist me!

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: We are so! a pox— take you.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Unkle, you must rise: so must your Lady— the charge of whom I give to my own dearest here.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Oh! how you Coxcombs shrugg, and Ogle this new Face already— 'Tis well my fine Fops, I shall have an hour for you too! Aside.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Now Phill. now Phill.— now or never little Phill.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Well Unkle— are you convinc'd yet of your old Error?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Oh Gracious Duke— I was a very Rascal— a Country Rogue! I do beseech your Grace, out of your mighty Bounty, to lift up your Noble Foot— and give me half a score good kicks! Kick me! my good Lord, I beseech you, do it.

sp.speaker: Cockle.
sp.p: No Unkle, not so neither: I remember you a little Familiar with me indeed!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Ah! Zoons I was bewitcht, my Lord, merely bewitcht, I call'd your Mighty Grace Son of a Whore: for which, besides my begging pardon on my knees, I was the Son of a Whore myself for my pains, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Well, well, 'Tis all forgotten, I know it was your zeal, and therefore blot it from my memory; have you, according to my Orders, resolved your self for Court, and utterly renounced the slavish Country, with all its Dirt and Care.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I have, so please you.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Have you dismist too your Garlick Eating-houshold, your Hobnail'd Lubbers, with their crook'd horn'd Noses, and dry chopt Hands.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: All, all, my Lord: All but my Man Roger there!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: You mean that Booby yonder— foh— how he looks! put him in Livery, or let me see him no more; away with him: I hate a fellow in Grey, like a Badger!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Oh Lord! What am I to be hang'd now?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: And have you sold your hangings of Nebuchadnezzar, and the Prodigal, with the antient History of Baalam's Ass, piec'd out with the Wisdom of Solomon, and the Two Harlots.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: All taken down, my Lord, and ready for a Chapman.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: 'Tis well, for now your Mind must quite be alter'd, as your Condition shall be: One word more in private I must impart to you— your Ear a little.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: In troth, my Lord, I am unworthy.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: No more words: Come hither when I bid you: whisper.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: As I was telling you first, your Husband must learn Basset, and must be no more your Master.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: No forsooth: I warrant you I'le order him.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Change that forsooth for Madam, when you talk.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Yes Madam! Oh Iemini! this is rare, I vow.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nor must you Eat with him, nor keep him company! If you would make him great; you see this Duke here,

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Yes forsooth,— Madam— I mean

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: He was an Ass when he came first to Town, an arrant Ass: Nay, I may truly call him just such another Coxcomb as your Husband— Till I push'd on his Fortune. No more words now: Come to me to Morrow— I'le put you in a way—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, well, Iv'ads I'm sure I shall be a Dutchess too, methinks I'm too proud for a Country Gentlewoman already— aside.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Think on my words, and so farewel for this time: Gentlemen, conduct my Unkle to his Lodging.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I am your Graces Slave, your Vassal! My Lord— Ah Gadsooks I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Oh! for a private place to ease my Lungs— I am ready to burst! such a pair of Jades— were never ridden sure.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Take him aside— Good Ned, whilst I break in upon the body of his strength, his Wife.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Advance then, and be hang'd, why don't you board her?

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Ply her to windward, ye Rogue! she rides fairly.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, you have taken the most compendious way, to raise your self; if his Grace stand your friend, you must be a great man! to Grub.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Why, troth he puts me in great hopes, Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: What do you think now, Sir, as first step to your preferment, if you could get to be Dew-beater!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: A Dew-beater; what a Devil's that?

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Why, your Office is to walk before the King a Mornings, and beat the Dew off: I see you have a good large flat Foot for the business.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Yes, yes, my Foot would do well enough, you need no doubt: But what's that Gentleman doing with my Wife yonder!

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Oh, what's matter what they are doing, or Sir, if you love your ease— suppose you should put in for Gentleman of the Charcole.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Gentleman of the Charcoal.

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Ay ay— To see good Fires made in all the Rooms about the Court, and disperse News to all the Courtiers that come to warm 'em. This place brings in a mint of Mony, if you can persuade 'em but to pay well.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Ods-heart! I persuade a Courtier to pay well! that were a work indeed— Put pray Gentlemen, by your leave, A little— I don't love to see my Wife hugg'd thus!

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Not love to see your Wife hugg'd? have a care what you say, Sir, I would not have the Gentleman hear you for a thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: What a Devil care I what he hears: pray, let me go Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Not for the World, Sir, s'life do you know what you do?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: The matter! He's one of the greatest Favourites at Court, And one that can do any thing with the King; I swear you are a lost Man if you stir.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: If you have a mind to Rise, Sir, never mind 'em.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Zoons, Sir,— They are kissing!

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Let 'em kiss, and much good do their hearts, if your Wife can but niggle him right, Sir— you are a made Man, I can tell you that.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: But Sir, to kiss her, and in that rumpant manner!

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Ay, ay, any manner, Sir: they must kiss, and double kiss: and kiss agen: or you may kiss the Post for your preferment.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I know not— but look, look: he's at it again!

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Agen and agen too: and the more happy Man you: would he would kiss me as much, or my Sister, or any of our Family.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Good b'we, Hubby, good b'we, Hubby—

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Zooks, Sir, but this is unconscionable, do but see, he has taken her into a private room.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Has he! why then your business will be done, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Her Business will be done, you mean, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: You'l be the happiest Man by this days work, except the Duke your Cosin, of any in the Court; For my part I envy you, and will Marry certainly, and not let every Man out-run me thus; 'tis time to be my own Friend now: I live in Court here, and teach the readiest way to prefer others, and be a slave myself.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir— be not mov'd— I thank you heartily for your Instructions, but—

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: But, no more but— but come away.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I should be glad, methinks, to have my Wife with me.

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Yet agen, your Wife! will you ruine all? Go, go! begone! and take no notice where you left her: let her return at leisure. If She stay a Month 'twill be the better— I tell you once more, that Gentleman can make ye—

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: A Cuckold it may be.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What he pleases, Sir!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Well— I will go! and dost hear Phill, don't forget Hubby a Duke, Phill. a Duke! be sure to remember Hubby! Gentlemen, your most Humble Servant— I'le leave 'em together for a time; since 'tis the Court-way— Gentlemen— your most Humble.

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Ha ha ha. To me the gulling of this Fool is Venery.

p.hi: Thus Country-Fops, that of Court-Grandeur heard, Post up to Town; and thus they are preferr'd.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: ACT V.
div.p: TIs somwhat strange; that I have had no Letters, nor no Accompt of my Affairs in the Country, since I sent Toby down among my Tenants: I did expect the very Bells of Dunstable, giving the sound to the near neighb'ring Steeples, would lead the joyful Tidings, like a Train of Gunpowder, from thence to London; But I hear nothing: Fame has lost her Trumpet, and the loud voice of my young flourishing Glory is mute as a hoarse Clerk setting a Psalm. A noise within.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sirrah, keep back— here's no place, for such Vermin: This is no Barn for Beggars.

div.stage: Enter Toby in a Blanket, forcing the Servant forward.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Beggars! here's a Rogue now! to rank a Great Dukes Secretary, because he appears a little in disguise, amongst Beggars.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Ye sawcy Rascal, you will come on! nay then, I'le try my strength— Goes to force him

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter there?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord, the Duke! do you know me: 'Tis I my Lord— 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What! Toby!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ay! ay! Faith old Toby of the World, that has such things to discover! such a Catastrophe to tell you: Hark you, Squire of the Curry-comb— To the Servant. You may go to your Stable, and make Love to your Coach-Mares! What a pox, because a Gentleman returns home a little in Disabillum! you cannot know him agen, you Rascal, can you; go rub rub; avant Oat-stealer. Turn out.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: What, Mr. Toby? this is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Sure thou hast design'd some Farce to entertain me! What is the meaning of all this! What Catastrophe hast thou to tell me?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh! a damn'd Catastrophe: as I was saying, a Devilish Plot— Will your Grace be pleas'd to call for a clean Shirt: Gad! it will make you sweat through your Cloaths in a moment.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What are all my Tenants run away in the Country? What a Devil can this be?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Nay, that the Fates can tell, not I: I have been no nearer the Country than I am now: Ah, your Grace little thinks, how dang'rous 'tis to be an Officer in Trust! why, since I saw you, I have been!—

sp.speaker: Cock
sp.p: In a Bawdy-house; I believe: Ay, ay; it must be so: And there stript: this sly Rogue has been in a Bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Bawdy-house at Bantam, my Lord— Too hot a Country for Whoring, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Bantam!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: E'en so: I was within a stones throw of it, for above two hours, I am sure: Does not your Grace begin to sweat yet?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: To hear you lye, Rascal.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Nay— if you doubt this— What will you do when you hear that I have been hang'd, drawn, and quarter'd for High Treason, since I saw ye.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Away— Coxcomb— Thou art drunk sure.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Drunk, it is with the Cup of Sorrow then, nothing but my Tears have moisten'd me. Since I saw you last,— I am as dry as a Bakers Bavin, and fit for nothing— but to be thrown in with them to heat an Oven: for since I left your Graces House.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: My House— what House is that, hah?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why, this House, your Graces House here!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: This House— why you Son of a Hedg Hog: has it no name, has my House no name! no Title, Sirra— Dunstable-House, ye Ass. Must a Man be always telling you these things?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p:
I beg your Graces pardon— And as I was saying, my Lord— just as I had left Dunstable-House, there comes up to me a Devil of a Fellow, Friend, says he— and stares me
in the Face— You are the Man beset— Come instantly with me, and be shipt away for Bantam, or you'l be instantly apprehended, and hang'd for High Treason.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: A Devil of a Fellow indeed: it must be some mad Man, sure.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Mad man! no— he was a Polititian I am sure, for he was mightily given to Musick, and Sung one profound Ballad, that to my knowledge, was made of on old— Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: This must be some Spy from some foreign Enemy; coud'st not thou have train'd him to Dunstable-House, that I might have examin'd him.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: No more than I could carry Dunstable-House upon my Back to Dunginess— Oh he had a plaguy pate of his own, and was, I am sure, a great Courtier, for he was in 20 several Minds in the space of a minute. First, he was for cloathing me in a disguise to escape, within a minute after— Wheigh— with a Powder le pimp, He fleas me, as a Cook does an Eel; after which I ran away, and not being able to get into Dunstable-House by mere chance— my shoul Joy, ish borrow'd thish Irish Cloak here of an honest Clanbriggian of my acquaintance; and lay all night perdue in thy little worshipful place, call'd Dunstable Privy-house indeed.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: There must be more in this, than at present I see, which at better leisure I will fist into: In the mean time, get ye in and uncase; You are a fine Secretary indeed—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: The Truth on't is at present, I look more like a Sow-gelder than a Secretary; the Learned observe, Men of Merits often taste the greatest misfortunes— Well Sir, I'll go and uncase, as your Grace Commands— little does he think that the Man in the Rugg here has his Fortune told to be as great as himself shortly. But Mum, Toby— There's some comfort still, however. Aside.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p:
Now I have consider'd o'nt, Since Toby's intended Journy is so crost, My State and Grandeur will much more be shewn Appearing in my person in the Country; My Tenants needs must be much better satisfy'd, with seeing me, than hearing of my Greatness:
It shall be so; I'le down to 'em this Morning. Who waits there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Go tell your Ladies Grace; that She must rise, I have instant business with her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Would your Grace have her rise to do your Business?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Yes that I would, Minx! here's a young Pert Quean already.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Lord, 'tis cold, and she may catch an Ague!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why then I'le Trot her till she catch a Feaver to't, How now, dare you dispute?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am gone, my Lord— on my life he's mad agen.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: There is no way to grow popular like Courtesie, A gracious Nod, a wink, or such a trifle will gain the People Love and Approbation, more than a thousand Messages, or How-de'es.

div.p: — Oh! are you come, Wife?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What, is the House on Fire, or has your Grace A fit of the Vertigo— that I am rowz'd thus?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Oh neither! neither!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What then, in the name of Wonder?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why, I am resolv'd, on good Consideration This day to see the Country, and 'tis proper That we set forward early.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The Country— for Heavens sake, my Lord, What is't you mean? Have you forgot the King's Request?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Prithee! I'le but shew myself: I'le only air my Titles there amongst 'em; and so return, which, by your leave, good Wife, will be for the King's Honor.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well, you may leave me here, you know I am breeding.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Oh! Air will do you good.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Besides, I dare not forfeit my Allegiance. Your Grace may do your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Your Allegiance! That is, your Duty to obey your Husband: Go, go, I say: and bid your Maids pack up your things.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nay, pray my Lord be rul'd: you know the Coronet that now adorns your Head, descended by my management.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Yes, yes: and the other Ornaments that branch there, were all of your contriving: what then? go and dispatch, I say.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The King will surely hear on't; and Heaven knows What the result may be?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Well, well; I'le venture that: pray spare your Politicks, and do as you're Commanded.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Pray hear me, Sir!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Yet agen, Impertinence! where got you this presumption? Am I the Duke, or you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well, Sir, thô you are Duke, 'twas I that Dubb'd you.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Dubb'd me; nay, the truth is, you did Dubb me I believe; but no more of that now: obey my Will, or—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Will no Reason— take place?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: A Womans Reason! that's good i'faith— prithee away, go, go, good crooked Rib, and do not provoke me. I know what thou would'st say; the King will take it ill: Alas! thou dost not know, my main design is for his Glory, by this Expedition, which I'le recount to him at my return, and what I've done for his security, by diving into the Humors of the People: But these are Riddles to thee, Child— Begone, I say, and within an hour let your Duty wait i'th' Hall, with your Riding-dress on, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sir, you'l be undone!

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: A Dunce, shall I not be?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Yes— by my Faith.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Oh! nay, if you grow Malepert: I must take other measures: Hear me once more; if all things are not ready in that time, I'le have thee carry'd like an Essex Calf, ty'd Neck and Heels, stuffed in a pair of Panniers: and I my self will drive thee on before me— you shall know who I am? Ex. Cockl.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I do too well, for a dull stubborn blockhead, and know not how to mend thee; s'life, if this Humor hold, I am half undone, for I am engag'd this Afternoon to meet the Widow Tireman, pretty Mrs. Primm, and three or four of the Beaux Esprits, at my Lady Wagbums this Afternoon, with design to play Crimp, and break the Bank, the Pareli, and Sept et-l●va, being made by those we have the design upon, for we have agreed what Cards shall win, and Mr. Shufflewell is so adroit in managing, that 'tis impossible we should miscarry, and now in the instant, is this Beast for hurrying me into the Country, but I'le have another trick to divert that Instantly— He shall stay in spite of him. Maria!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Quick, quick; thou dost not dream, what Eggs are hatching; this Beast is for the Country agen; and all my dear Delights and Joys o'th' Town destroy'd in th' Instant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The Devil shall have him first.
I'le bring him one shall swear there's a great Flood,
And there's no likelyhood to pass this ten days.
Or that a party of 2000 Robbers have sworn to pillage for a week that Road; you know he loves his Money.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No, no, his Grace must be degraded; there's no way like it: Clermont and his Friends are all prepar'd for this last Plot; Therefore be swift as Thought, to find 'em out, we have but an hour of Trial.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Swift as the Mischief, Madam, never doubt me.

q.l: Since Marriage is a yoke two Fools must wear,
The ablest Fool the heaviest part should bear.
Thus let it then my Husbands Neck weigh down,
I'le try to make it easy for my own. Ex. Aur.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: What! lye out two whole nights, and no preferment come, yet; How hast thou spent thy time?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh! very well indeed Hubby! for the Gentleman told me you should be a great huge Man; very suddenly. And for joy of it you can't Imagine Hubby, how I briskt up to him!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Briskt up to him, a pox, thô you briskt up to him so mightily! nothing comes on't, that I see.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh! all in good time, Hubby, for he told me the King had knowledge of you already: And how you were resolv'd to be a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Hush, here comes Mr. Secretary!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Run you, and see the Sumpter got ready; and let my Lords Cloaths be brush'd, and laid in order; tht Trunks and Boxes see nail'd fast, and corded, d'e hear? To a Serv.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: What's the matter, good Mr. Secretary!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oownz! Sir, my Lord's going Post into the Country o'th' sudden— I am almost out of my wits here.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: The Country:

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ay ay, Sir, nay, prithee Mr. Justice, you see I've a world of Business upon my hands— and d'ye hear, put the Womens things in the new Panniers, the Linen, and the Box of Cordial Waters: Bid Nurse take care of my Ladies Eagle Stone too: I hear she's breeding.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I will, Sir! Ex. Serv.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: The rest I'le do myself: Oh! how I sweat— Exit.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Roger: this suits well for me, for when he's gone, my Wife alone can do my business better: Odzooks, I strangely long to be preferr'd, that I may twit my Neighbours in the Country, and contradict our Parson, that's a main matter.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Zo 'tis! ant' shall please you: and that will make him contradict all the Parish.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: And never fear me Hubby— I'le push it forward.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Do, do, Phill. do: Why, well said, Phill: methinks I am o'rejoyd at the conceit on't: But see, here comes his Grace.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Why, this is well now: though you can talk, I see you understand Obedience.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.
Alas! 'tis all poor Women were design'd for.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Very Good. Very Good! Oh Unkle. I did not see you. Why, I must court your Patience, some few days to live without me: We Great Men Dive somtimes: 'Tis a State trick that you are yet unskill'd in: But have patience, we shall appear agen to your satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Health to your Graces both.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Set forward then: Sure Toby has by this time pack't up the things, and seen the Coach got ready?

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Stand, thou proud Man, once more I bid thee stand.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Thieves, Thieves! where are my People all? who waits there?

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Let 'em stir if they dare. And thus I am to say: Thou haughty Man, Thou art a Monster; for thou art ungrateful, and like a fellow of a Rebel nature; hast flung from his embraces; therefore he bids thee stand, thou Insolent Man, whilst thus with whisking of my Sword about— I take thy Honor off; This first sad Whisk takes off thy Dukedom, Thou art but a Marquess.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: This second Whisk divides thy Marquifate; Thou art yet a Baron.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Prithee be quiet, I'le have no more of thy Whisks: what a Devil dost think I am an Ass.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: You must have patience.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Oh! that ever I was born.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! Oh!— Howls out.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p:
Two Whisks are past: and two are yet behind: yet all
must come: then not to linger time, with these two dismal Whisks I quite degrade thee now; Goodman Cocklebrain: for that sums all your Titles: Thank the King for punishing no further.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Oh! Undone, undone! I thought what his stubborness would bring him too? Feigns to weep.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: This cannot be in earnest, sure.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: You'l find it so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I am confounded, shot to the Brain, I know not where I am!

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Nay— for your part, my Gracious Lord, the Fates have a far different doom— To Grub.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: How's that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Glory attends you, what Honors flow upon you. This Patent will inform your Grace— Gives a Patent.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: My Grace! s'heart— if this should be a Dream now And yet I feel the Parchment in my hand: Good Sir, explain your meaning— you have transform'd me.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: — Hum, hum!

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Thus then in short, my Lord: The King who still so much preserves the memory of that unhappy Man to let the Honors remain in's Blood, has in his stead, made you the Duke of Dunstable; And as such, he bids you wear this Robe of State.

div.stage: Puts a Antick Robe and Turbant on his Head.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Godzooks! Why Phill. Am I awake, Art sure I am awake Phill?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Ods- diggers! I must be a Secretary too I see, there's no remedy!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Hubby! and did not I make the most of a thing, think you, to get to be a Dutchess so soon?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Zooks, Thou hast made more of a thing, Girl, than ever Dutchess did— I am all Air: Gad I can fly, methinks— A Duke already; why this is prodigious.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Your Grace, I hope, will remember your poor Servant.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: O Lord, dear Sir— you shall have any thing.

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: I must beg leave to make my Court to her Grace, that way I am sure preferment lies.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Oh! by all means, Sir. Do'st hear, dear Wife: we must be civil to these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Well, well— the Gentlemen know I han't been behind hand with 'em.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: False Villain: 'Tis as I suspected now, thô late, I see his Treachery, and will revenge myself, thô I undo 'em all. Aside.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Iohn Cocklebrain, thô the Kings Kings Royal Judgment has at last found where he should place his Honors: it is not fit thou shouldst be quite forgot— Iohn, come to my House, and Eat somtimes, dost hear! I'le get thee into the Guards, or somewhere, because thou art my Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: The Guards— ods-heart I'de as leive 'twere the Gallows. Oh! Oh— I shall run mad.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Mad! you Jackanapes! han't I told you of your fantastical Humors a thousand times: Thou fit to be a Duke! Alas poor Fellow!

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: My Lord! the Coachman stays: and all your Equipage, rank'd by my Care and and Order, wait your Motion; I have had the Devil and all to do amongst 'em yonder; but they are ready at last.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! Oh! Looking discontentedly on Grub. who looks scornfully on him.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Hey-day! What Farce is now to be acted? What is Mr. Justice going a Morice-dancing?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Make him cease his babling, Friends: and then let the poor Rascal know who I am.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Who you are, why you are a Cuckold, and a Justice of Peace— I know▪ who you are well enough.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: How's that? Have you a mind to be hang'd, Sirra?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, are you all mad?

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Sirra! he's newly made a Duke, down o'your knees, or—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Duke! yes; and so am I as much? What d'e think I do not know old Justice Grub?

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Nay— if the Fellow grows saucy, let him be whipt, d'e hear, and then toss'd in a Blanket: 'Tis fit I begin a little severely. T'will make me the more terrible.

sp.speaker: Clerm. Long.
sp.p: Away, away with him: you are a saucy Knave indeed.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why, my Lord the Duke— help, help.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: What a Devil is the meaning of this, S'heart, you will not let me be toss'd in a Blanket, will you?

div.stage: Enter Bewford, and a Boy with a Robe and Cap.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Not for the World, unbind him, Gentlemen, upon your perils.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: Why how now, Bewford, whence comes this Insolence, that you dare contradict his Graces Order.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: His Grace! You'l find he has no such Title!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Oonz— but I have, Sir, and will maintain it. Dare you sight, Sir? ha. Offers to draw.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Oh! Rage will do no good, Sir. To explain all, Gentlemen, thus it is, All you have acted hitherto, is by mistake, a Courtier, that his Lady made her friend, made shift to steal his name into a Patent, but now 'tis raz'd out; and instead of him the King has chosen this Noble Gentleman; and this is now the Duke.

div.stage: Claps Toby on the Back, and Looks big.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Hem, Hem.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: His Majesty has heard of your wise Conduct, and with this Robe invests you. Puts on an Antick Robe

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Air, air, good friends! by my troth this news warms mightily.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: And if for this good news, I may deserve to kiss your Graces Hand, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My Hand: Faith Friend I'le have it wash'd first— Dost hear, old Fellow: prithee fetch me a Bason of Water. To Grub.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Fetch a Halter, Come, draw, draw: I'le fight for't: I'le not be chows'd out of a Dukedom so, not I: since you have these tricks, I'le take the right way to secure my Title, and settle it by the Sword. Draw, Draw, I say.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Ay, ay— Draw, as my Lord Duke says: Zowns! I'le thrash some of you!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Oh! there must be no Bloodshed.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: The old Fool has often these Fits: some of you that wou'd deserve my Favour, take the old Dotard away, and toss him in a Blanket a little: there's nothing like it to cure his Fits.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: How, Sirra! a Blanket: s'bud can I bear all this?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Have but patience, Unkle, and I'le speak to his Grace, to take you as under Butler, or somthing: I know you come to Town for preferment.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Fool. Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Ay, look at home, Unkle! my Aunt has stirr'd her stumps, you know!

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: A pox stirr her.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Nay, pray Hubby be not so angry: you know I did all for the best.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, Whore— but do you hear Gentlemen! Have I dreamt all this while of Dignity, and am I really no Duke?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: No, no: Friend! a Duke! I prithee call thy Wits agen.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: What thô I formerly rail'd against the Court, when I was not preferr'd— I have more Honesty and Conscience now— for if I am a Duke—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yet agen a Duke! Why, thou art no more a Duke, than thou art a Dromedary; but as poor a Clumsie, Clod-pated old Justice as ever was drunk with March Beer at a Sheriffs Feast.

div.stage: Enter Vsher of the Black Rod, Aurelia, and a Guard.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Ownz! How I could swinge these Rogues, if I had my Will— What, my Wife lye with a topping Courtier two whole nights, and I no Duke! 'tis impossible?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I tell thee once more, thou art no Duke: I think the old Fellow is bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: No, no; nor you neither, good Yeoman of the Roppets I shall Un-Duke you.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: Ha! The Usher of the Black Rod! would I were safe at my Lodging.

sp.speaker: Clerm. Bewf.
sp.p: And I. And I.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: Guard— Seize those Duke makers, disarm 'em: nay, if you struggle, we shall hamper you: Here's a Warrant to bring you before the King and Council. You are for disposing the King's Honors, and granting Dignities; let's see now— how you'l dispose your Estates to pay 20000 l. a piece Fine— besides 7 years imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: This I have help'd ye to, my lewd Court-swaggerers! you are for every Face you see, you are for flying at all Games: You! but I'le teach you to affront your Friends.

sp.speaker: Bewf.
sp.p: Ah! malitious Devil, we shall get off some time or other.

sp.speaker: Longo.
sp.p: And then the World shall know you.

sp.speaker: Clerm.
sp.p: What a fine Jilt you are.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Do, rail, rail; poor fools.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I begin to shake: what is the meaning of all this!

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: As for your part, my Lord of Lubberland.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Lubberland; prithee Friend thou mistak'st my Title, I am Duke of Dunstable.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: A Duke, a Dog-whipper you are! such a knot of Fools, that the King, instead of punishing, pities you— But I shall make bold to turn you out of your Dignitie, my Lord Duke.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Heyday, the World's turning upon wheels, sure, What-a-devil d'e take me for.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: For a Fool I take you, I confess.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Fool, you might as well have taken me for an Alderman, But prithee don't trouble thy Head, man.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: Sirra: leave your fooling, and have a care of the Porters Lodge; there are Whips with Bells: and so I take my leave of all your Graces: you Cocklebrain, you shall scape for your Wives sake, because she is my Kinswoman— But for the rest, away with 'em. Exeunt Guards, with the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Your Humble Servant, my Lord Duke.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Ah! the Devil take this confounded Town: wou'd it were burnt agen— Will your Grace have a little more Air.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p:
Thank your Grace; I am very cool o'th' sudden: Besides,
I am reflecting upon the strange mutability of human Affairs— But however the world goes, Brethren— let's make some shew of our Dignity, before we part: What think you of Dancing the Hey?

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: To be thus fool'd, and in my old age— well.

div.stage: Here they Dance the Hey, and whilst they are Dancing; Enter Lyonel in a mad posture, with Celia, Doctor, Singers and Dancers.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Hah! here they are! and in the height of Revelling Pluto, Minos, Radamanthus, the King of the Infernals, and the Judges.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.l: Oh the Devil: here's the Mad man agen—
Come, come away. Come, Dutchess, Troop.
I'le not stay an hour in this cursed Town.
D'e hear, Sir, that 500 l. must be paid back again.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Not a penny, Unkle, your Grace shall take it out in Offices—

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Plague take you all: Zowns! You Whore, Come away.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh! dear Hubby. Shall I never see a Play, nor lye abroad agen? Weeps.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: What! you have a mind to be a Dutchest agen: have you? Come away, and be hang'd, I'le Dutchess you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: A Plague of this cursed Town, if this be all one gets!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Great Pluto— know that I am Orpheus, and through the dismal shades of direful night, am come to seek my long lov'd Proserpine, I'le charm thee God, with Musick, my soft Aires shall lull the Pow'rs of thy barb'rous Empire, and set my Love at liberty. Sings.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Pray, sooth his Humor. Till we can lay hold on him, then never doubt his Cure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Madam, I thought he had been seiz'd before.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: He was, but by main strength he broke away; his Madness still increasing: These are People plac'd by the Doctors Order, to humor the distemper.

div.stage: They seize him, and carry him out▪

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: So, now Madam, never give belief to Art, if you to Morrow, find him not recover'd.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Heaven grant he may, he shall not want my wishes.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Nay, Gentlemen: a little of your help will be convenient.
Brothers by Title, what think you to divert our selves, if we should Act a Farce, and that we call it The three Dukes of Dunstable.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Not I; I have been in a Farce lately enough: but I am resolv'd to go into the Country— Eat nothing but Turnips 7 years, to recover the Estate I have spent in waiting for preferment, and never so much as look towards old Sodom here agen.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And thus, Sir, on my knees, I promise ye henceforth to be Conforming to your pleasure with all the Care, and Diligence, and Duty of a most Penitent, Obedient Wife, to atone for my past Follies: and no more to heed the senseless Fopperies of the Town, nor the more senseless Fops remaining in it.

sp.speaker: Cockl.
sp.p: Well— I am forc'd to believe thee: We that are Married, have but small variety of remedy.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I have been fool'd my share too. But for my part, ince it is so— I'le off with my Mantle de la Guerr here, and into the Barn, and Thresh agen: there's no Revolution of State there, if the Harvest be but good; And if ever I expect to be exalted agen, may I be hang'd upon a Beam there, in one of our own Cart-ropes.

q.l: And may no Fool for better Fortune look;
That just from Digging, thinks to be a Duke:

div.head: EPILOGUE:
div.p: Of which (because it was particularly carp'd at) I desire every one that has more Wit than Malice, to Judge.
div.l: FOnd of his Art; the Poet has to day
Mistook, and made me mad the silliest way;
Pride, Wealth, or Wine, may Frenzy often move:
But that's a strange Brute that runs mad for Love,
Few now, Thank Heaven, such lewd examples find,
'Tis forfeiting the Charter of our Kind;
Shall Men have all, and Women no remorse?
Then let the Cart hereafter drag the Horse.
Let each Eve wrest the Scripture false, and swear;
She was not made for Man, but Man for Her;
No, this had been a most unpardon'd Crime;
Did not the Lady here repent in time.
Besides, the Notion's false, for sure no Man
Can Love so well, and faith no Woman can:
'Tis true, degrees of Madness all may fit,
Some with too much, some with too little Wit,
I have been Mad, or I should ne'r have Writ.
'Tis a Disease that Reigns in every station,
First, amongst Gamesters I have found occasion,
Somtimes to make a pretty Observation;
At Hazard I have seen a Witty Lad
Eat up a Candle, if his luck were bad;
What think ye, Sirs, Was not that Fellow mad?
A Lady too, in Tears has left off Play
(Alas poor Punt,) for losing Sonica,)
But above all, Wine does worst Frenzy raise,
For then Fop comes, and Whistles at our Plays,
Calls some one Whore, that to some Spark belongs,
Who calls him out, and whips him through his Lungs.
This, on our Nation, a vile blot remains
None but the Dutch and English take such pains
To fill the Paunch, and empty all the Brains.
The last, worst sort too, does your Heads invade,
That's Whoring, that Vice makes ye all stark mad:
Not Poverty has power to stop its force,
Poor Rogues, that ne'r could pay their Alehouse Scores
Shall brag they've at Command a Leash of Whores.
To th' Camp those Militant Doxies yearly stray
Where each mad flitt'ring Fool that's given that way
To purchase Pox, melts down a whole Months Pay.
Many more Theams of Madness I could name,
And quote; indeed too many to our shame.
But, Sirs, to prove that you have all your Wits,
Let every Critick, that in Iudgment sits,
Our Poet to an easie Penance doom,
Wink at small faults, for all of you have some.

div.head: PLAYS Printed for Henry Herringman, and Sold by Ioseph Knight, and Francis Saunders.

list.head: By Sir George Etherege.
list.item: The Man of Mode, or Sir Fopling Flutter.

item.hi: Tyrannick Love, or the Royal Martyr.

list.head: By Mr. Shadwell.
list.item: Timon of Athens alter'd by Him

list.head: By Sir Samuel Tuke, and several Persons of Honour.

div.p: NEW SONGS SUNG IN The Fool's Preferment, OR, THE Three DUKES of Dunstable.
In the SAVOY: Printed by E. Iones, for Ios. Knight and Fran. Saunders, at the Blue Anchor in the Lower-Walk of the New Exchange in the Strand, 1688.

div.head: A Song sung in the First Act.
div.p:
I Sigh'd, and I pin'd, I sigh'd, and I pin'd, was constant, was constant, and kind, to a Jilt that laugh╌'d at my Pains; tho' my Pas╌sion ne're cool'd, I found I was fool'd, for all my a╌bun╌dance of Brains; tho' my Pas╌sion ne're
cool'd, I found I was fool'd, for all my a╌bun╌dance of Quick. Brains: But now I'm a Thing, as grea╌t as a King, so blest is the Head that is ad╌dle; the dull empty Pate, soonest comes to be great, Fate dotes on a Fool in the Cradle.

THere's nothing so fa╌tal as Woman, to hur╌ry a Man to his Grave; you may Think, you may Plot, you may Sigh like a Sot, she u╌ses you more like a Slave: But a Bottle, altho' it be common, the Cheats of the Fair will un╌do;
it will drive from your Head, the Delights of the Bed, he that's Drunk, is not a╌ble to Woo.

div.head: A Song sung in the Third Act, by Mr. Monfort.
div.p:
FLed is my Love, for e╌ver, for e╌ver, e╌ver, gone! O╌h, mighty Loss! E╌ter╌nal Sor╌row, E╌ter╌nal Sorrow! Yet prethee Strephon, why should'st mourn? For if thy Ce╌lia
wont re╌turn, to her thou shalt go, to her thou shalt go to mor╌row; to her thou shalt go, to her thou shalt go to morrow.

TIS Death alone, 'tis Death a╌lone, can give me Ease, for all the mighty Pain, for all the mighty Pain, I've felt; in his cold Tomb my Heart shall e╌ver freeze, since hers could ne╌ver, ne╌ver mel╌t; since hers could ne╌ver, ne╌ver mel╌t, could ne╌ver melt.

I'Le mount to you blue Cae╌lum, to shun those Female Gypsies, I'le play at Bowls with Sun and Moon, and scare you, scare you, scare you with E╌clip╌ses; and scare you, scare you, scare you with E╌clip╌ses.

I'Le sail up╌on the Dog╌Star, I'le sail up╌on the Dog╌Star, and then persue the Morning, and then persue, and then persue the Morning; I'le chase the Moon 'till it be Noon, I'le chase the Moon 'till it be Noon, but I'le make, I'le make her leave her Horning.
I'le climb the fro╌sty Mountain, I'le climb the frosty Mountain, and there I'le coyn the Weather; I'le tea╌r the Rain╌bow from the Sky, I'le tea╌r the Rain╌bow from the Sky, and tye, and tye both ends to╌ge╌ther. The Stars pluck from their Orbs too, the Stars pluck from their Orbs too, and
crowd them in my Budget; and whether I'm a roa╌ring Boy, a roa╌╌ring Boy, let all╌, let all the Nation judge it.

div.head: A Scotch Song sung in the 4th Act.
A Dialogue by Jockey and Jenny.

sp.speaker: Iockey.
sp.p: IEnny, gin you can love, and have resolv'd you will try me; sil╌ly Scruples remove, and do no lon╌ger de╌ny me: By thy bonny Black Eye, I swear nean other can move me; Then if still you deny, You never, never did love me.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Iockey, how can you mistake, that know full well when you woo me; My poor Heart does so ake, it throbs as it would come through me! How can you be my Friend, That thus are bent to my Ruine? All the Love you pretend, Is only for my Undoing.

sp.speaker: Iockey.
sp.l: Who can tell by what Art
This Chiming Nothing, called Honour,
Charms my Ienny's soft Heart,
When Love and Iockey has won her?

lg.l: And Muckle Woe there's about it;
Than live in Scandal without it.
But if you'l love me, and Wed;
And guard my Honour from Harms too;
Iockey I'le take to my Bed,
And fold him close in my Arms too.

sp.speaker: Iockey.
sp.l: Talk not of Wedding, dear Sweet,
For I must have Chains that are softer;
I'm of a Northerly Breed,
And never shall love thee well after.

lg.head: CHORUS: Bass and Treble.
lg.l: Our Amity shall be no dearer;
Still let us kiss and be friends,
And sigh we shall never come nearer.

div.head: A Song sung in the Fifth Act by Mr. Monsort.
div.p:
IF thou wilt give me back my Love, for e╌ver I'le A╌dore thee; and for the fa╌vour, mighty Iove, with Souls from Heaven shall store thee: To the Queen of Shades, she shall advance, and all shall wait up╌on her;
Kings shall A╌dore her Countenance, and I'le be her Page of Ho╌nour.
